title: The erasure of refugees in Westerbork

page_blocks.text: In November 2018 the Westerbork Memorial and Stichting Vluchteling (the Netherlands main refugee foundation having its roots in the Second World War) announced as a special 10th edition of the Night of the Refugee on the European Day of the Refugee for June next year an extra long-distance walk starting in the middle of the night in camp Westerbork to Groningen. Although the memorial has commemorated the refugee history tied in with the Westerbork site regularly, the organization received threats and hefty critiques in January 2019. Most of these were contesting the link between Westerbork and the general refugee issue in the Netherlands as a contrived connection.

page_blocks.text: Several Jewish organizations accused the directorship of the memorial of tainting this Holocaust space. Others argued that “in the 1930s, Jews were gassed, killed, while many refugees are received with open arms”. At the same time, the conservative political organizations and the new-right populist party Forum voor Democratie supported the attack on the “leftist club” of Camp Westerbork. Jewish and rightwing social media activists both hinted in twitter messages at the “shameful” Holocaust denial triggered by this event, and vehemently argued against the association between the memorial site and human rights principles. When the director of Westerbork retired, he described it as the absolute low of 30 years of profession. He was surprised not by the usual accusations of the radical right, but the unusual protests from inside the Jewish community. Some even suggested protesting wearing the camp garments. Because of the seriousness of the accusations and the opposition, the event had to be cancelled, also at the advice of the authorities who could not guarantee the safety of staff and refugees. The situation suggests that at such places heritage, and their mainstream symbolism are read and understood through the vantage point of the present, as the past is used for claims of ownership and othering.

page_blocks.text: This case of competing memories, between the history of the European Holocaust and the pre-war refugee crisis, is evidently a reaction to the harsh tone of the contemporary times and the current European refugee crisis. However, it speaks more broadly about how the history of the rise of authoritarianism in Europe in the 1930s has been quietly erased from this history of camps and sites of political violence in Europe. Indeed, little of the precarious position of European Jewish refugees in 1938 in the Netherlands was of interest during the debate , although the neglect of this history has been an enduring staple of the discussions about accountability in the Netherlands in the last decades. It has subsided, however, exactly at a time when issues of responsibility would be relevant for the wider political and public sphere. In contrast to other camps, Westerbork was originally built as a Centraal-Jewish Refugee camp funded by the community, and because of the Nazi-German occupation changed in 1942 from a refugee camp for Jews into a transit camp. This background as a refugee camp supported the deceptive, humane façade of the following Polizeiliches Judendurchgangslager Westerbork, which made it into one of the Third Reich’s most operational West-European gates to the hell of the Central and Eastern European Nazi-German concentration and extermination camps.

page_blocks.text: The present debate however re-emphasizes that Westerbork is uniquely evocative of the Holocaust. It has been the staple history confirmed in 2013 when the memorial received one of the first European heritage labels, together with the Hague Peace Palace. As a European ‘site of memory’, the committee report mentioned it represents Europe’s darkest history with which the EU wanted to break with, and an opportunity to strengthen EU international collaboration for younger generations. This fomulation alone speaks about the “negative founding myth” of the Holocaust for Europe (i) Westerbork at home is, however, still regarded an exclusive historical space of the national Dutch Holocaust and the tragedy of the Jewish deportations.

page_blocks.text: Such a national gaze reduces in fact the complex international, longer-term history which led to the rise of Nazism, German expansionism, Jewish mass migration, war and occupation, ghettoisation and the camp system, and the ‘final solution’ which were truly a transnational phenomena. There were over 20 nationalities among the 107,000 Jews transported to the East. Most of these members of a European Jewish community came to the Netherlands after 1933, with the rise of antisemitic politics in Germany and Austria, but there were others taking refuge from other forms of antisemitism or anti Jewish politics in Eastern Europe after World War I. Even among the Ashkenazi, known in the Netherlands as “German Jews”, many were descendants of Yiddish speaking refugees from the 17th c. German Thirty Years War up to the late 19th c. Russian and Polish pogroms, whereas the established Sephardim (known as “Portuguese Jews”) had settled in 16th-17th Amsterdam as refugees from the Spanish Inquisition.

The postcolonial “blankspot”

page_blocks.text: But it was not only this national selective knowledge that the debate stressed. The camp was built after the refugee policy changed dramatically in Europe in 1938. After a first wave of migration of some 38,000 Jews to neighbouring countries, mostly political opponents escaping Nazi-Germany after Hitler’s 1933 rise to power, The exclusion of Jews from German public life, as proclaimed in the 1920 Programme of the Nazi Party, achieved by the Nuremberg race laws and Germany’s support of Jewish emigration, meant that lmost 30 per cent of the Jewish population had left the country still without the threat of genocide. The March 1938 Anschluss of Austria and the following Austrian-Jewish migration wave aggravated the conditions. All very well received in Berlin, they created an example soon to be followed by the German Reichskristallnacht, or November Pogrom. This was a nation-wide Nazi organised ‘popular fury’ against everything Jewish, mainly shops, synagogues and cemeteries, which - carefully organised by Gestapo and the SD. While Jews were robbed of their properties, 400 were killed, 30,000 sent to concentration camps, and another 113,000 (of a total of 523,000) German Jews fled to other countries during the next two years, despite the British and American immigration restrictions.

data.title: Arrests of refugees 1938

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: The erasure of refugees in Westerbork

page_blocks.text:
In his first election speech in Köningsberg of 27 March 1938, directly after the Austrian Anschluss, Hitler responded to the American Secretary of State Cordell Hull’s call for an international committee for refugees with a promise to “our newly united German Volk and Reich” of a total cleansing of the “incorrigible foes” [Jews], and for which he counted on full popular support by means of a referendum. Not having found any international opposition after the Anschluss and Kristallnacht, he now cynically approved the Hull plan: “I can only hope and expect that the other world, which has such deep sympathy for these criminals, will at least be generous enough to convert this sympathy into practical aid. We, on our part, are ready to put all these criminals at the disposal of these countries for all I care, even on luxury ships.”(Hitler is pleased to get rid of foes. Commenting on Hull's Plan He Says Some Opponents of Nazis Deserve to Die”, The New York Times, March 27, 1938).As Goebbels reported in his diary, if “nobody wants the scum!” there should be another way to remove them. In this way, as Ronnie Landau put it, the Evian conference triggered the change of the Nazi policy towards the ‘Final Solution’. (Landau (2006)).

The Netherlands was only fleetingly involved in efforts to temper this wave of refugees. When 32 countries assembled on president Roosevelt’s initiative in Evian (15), It was on hindsight the last opportunity to save the lives of Europe’s Jews, but the stalemate of the Evian conference only confirmed the complete lack of collective international opposition against the racial politics of Nazi Germany. The United States and Great Britain, facing Hitler’s policy of mass migration, refused to change their restricted immigration policy for ‘undesirable immigrants’, and appealed to Germany’s (soon occupied) neighbouring countries to act as the refugee’s main host countries (like the Netherlands). Eastern European countries, some of them already collaborating with Nazi Germany, refused to take part. The Anglo-Saxon dominated Evian Committee closed their meetings in October 1938 with a memorandum to the German Foreign Office, confirming that none of the assembled nations challenged the right of the German government to deal with its subjects as it liked, as no-one questioned its state sovereignty. (Evian Memorandum, October 1938, quoted in Ronnie S. Landau (2006).) This actually sent the unmistakable permission to all neighbours to close their borders. Chancellor Hitler could also presented himself to the world as a truly democratic leader.

page_blocks.text: The current debates around the internment in Westerbork show how the usage and the relevance of “illegality” have been conditioned and catalyzed in the late 1930s by the threat of war. Although Germany’s neighbouring countries Holland and Denmark were the only nations at the Evian Conference willing to increase their refugee quotas, also the Dutch authorities had been worried by the numbers of refugees crossing the border and the implications of their presence considering the widespread unemployment at the time (16). In the midst of the 1938 refugee crisis, access of Jewish refugees to the Netherlands was further restricted, which effectively overruled both the 1849 Act and the 1904 Dutch-German treaty allowing for “peaceful” Germans to cross the border at leisure.

data.title: Rise of unemployment in 1938

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: The erasure of refugees in Westerbork

page_blocks.text:
The reception of the newcomers in the 1930s was determined by the “Alien Act” of 1849, which was primarily meant to bar individuals who were presumably a possible charge and unwanted responsibility for the Dutch state from staying. The borders were accessible and individuals could stay without a work permit, in the sense that they were not illegal even if their permits had expired. In the 19th century, the primary concern was with the poor and working class, who could become troublesome citizens. Towards 1890, the direct target of this policy were mainly small groups of Hungarian Roma, which for a first time were named “Zigeuners”; this in contrast to the older Sinti nomads with Western-European passports, who were generally allowed to travel. The legislation was tightened only after the First World War, when foreign soldiers and no less than 2 million Belgium refugees entered the country of which many were housed, for a first time, in temporary refugee camps. Travelling without passports would become more difficult in Europe after the democratic success of the introduction of universal suffrage in 1918-19. With the German and Russian revolutions, there was fear for communist agitators to stay in the Netherlands. It strengthened the nationalism of governments now having to take care of citizens wanting to protect their national welfare against the “competition” of others. The 1930s economic crisis further strengthened the wish for protectionism against the competition from foreign German-Jewish businessmen for instance.

The possibilities of a Jewish refugee arriving from Germany to the Netherlands after 1933 were  gradually limited. As approximately 40,000 individuals crossed the border from Germany between 1933 and 1940 (more than a quarter of the total number of German-Jewish refugees) they were primarily seen as “economic migrants''. After May 1934, work permits were limited only for jobs which could not be performed by a Dutch citizen, and official policies restricted the possibility of long term accommodation. Permitted to stay were however still refugees who could sustain themselves financially.  Despite the prominence of many members of the Jewish community who had migrated from Eastern Europe because of a growing anti-Semitism, after Hitler’s rise to power in 1933 and his policy of mass migration after Kristallnacht, Dutch newspapers ran articles concluding “refugees are not welcome”. It had fostered the rise of the fascist NSB party who in Hitler’s footsteps succeeded in criminalising refugees and creating fears of disturbing the economic and social balance. Although when the national socialists entered the Netherlands national parliament in 1937, it received ‘only’ 4 percent of the votes, and was less powerful not only far less powerful than its big brother in Nazi Germany, but also much smaller than expected based on the 1935 provincial elections  . Fascism was no longer seen as an attractive escape from class struggle, but as a threat to war.

page_blocks.text: Testimonies of others having to take refugees in their homes, paint a more complex and often contradictory, though hardly happier picture, like the one of Hans Margules who later became an OD in Westerbork, which speaks about exclusion and isolation. News reports of the time convey the hopelessness of the situation.

data.title: Reactions to 1938-1939

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: The erasure of refugees in Westerbork

page_blocks.text:
Westerbork was built as a “central refugee camp” by Jewish unemployed already. In an effort of the government to activate workers who because of the economic depression lost their jobs, a system of labour camps was developed. Illegal refugees were then no longer allowed to work in regular jobs. They were, however, offered comparable reclamation and agricultural work in a new, almost military organised, fenced refugee camps such as Heijplaat in Rotterdam. In addition, small groups of German Jewish refugees found work in a number of Zionist kibbutzim and hakhshara (agricultural) training centres as to prepare themselves for emigration to Palestine. When the war broke out, Zionist pioneer camps like the Deventer Association (1918) and, in particular, the modern agricultural school complex Werkdorp Wieringermeer (1934) each had some three hundred workers occupied.Wieringermeer under its last Jewish director Abel Herzberg was evacuated in 1941 by the Amsterdam SD. Most refugees were sent to the new Amsterdam ghetto, from where with the second razzia (raid) on 11 June the majority of Werkdorp Jews were deported first to Camp Schoorl and from there, just like the victims of the first Amsterdam raid of 22-23 February (which would lead to the February Strike), to Mauthausen (Austria) where most of them died within a few months after arrival.

When the first occupants of Westerbork arrived, it brought a temporary respite in an otherwise precarious existence. Aanti-refugee sentiments were often stirred up on a local level by right-wing neighbours who did not like the idea of having foreigners in their countryside.

From the beginning of the German occupation also Dutch Jews were treated on paper already as potential refugees. This proved to become practice after the beginning of the deportations in February 1941, when there was little distinction being made anymore between Jewish residents and “stateless” German-Jewish refugees. Both groups were from then on treated in the same way as internees of the same transit camp waiting to be deported to the eastern labour-, concentration or extermination camps, sometimes the one treated more brutal, or offered more privileges than the other.

Jews were needed, on the one hand, for forced labour in the war industry, whereas on the other, war introduced more easy and violent ways to exclude the millions of Polish and Russian Jews in the newly occupied Eastern territories. It was to these regions that from mid 1942 also many Westerbork Jews were deported.

page_blocks.text: In transit camp Westerbork, the “Germans” (the first refugees who were concentrated after the building of the refugee camp) held the main service positions from the immediate opening in 1939 to almost the final period of the camp (24). Testimonies of German refugees speak about the growing rivalries with the “Dutch” after their arrival since July 1942. Dutch Jews associated the former refugees, now changed into higher ranged “camp eldest”, because of their common language, their often ‘collaborating’ role as members of the OD (Order Police, internal to the camp), and their possession of the best, family barracks, often with the German perpetrators (25). Both groups however were caught in a rivalry which had more to do with the history and microcosm of the camp than with their supposed national habits. (26) Their post-war lives, and the fact that relatively many of the camp elite survived the war, emigrated and rebuilt their lives, fueled this memory conflict until decades after the war (27).

data.title: Testimony of a priviledged inmate
data.description: Kurt Schlesinger was one of the initial German refugees interned in the camp, and came to supervise the transports. He was a witness in Gemmeker's trial but his own contribution to the deportations was rarely discussed. He emigrated, after several years to the United States, where he passed away in 1963. His testimony emphasizes the circumstances of his actions

page_blocks.text:
This ‘double’ refugee story is also part of the heritage of Westerbork. With the centrality of the Holocaust however in memory debates, the history of granting and losing rights and the way these contributed to the general tragedy of the war, what conditioned for survivors still who was “ours” and who was not, made way for the equalizing identity of Holocaust victims.

This has created the mistaken image as if Jews were already from the beginning of the Third Reich threatened by genocide. Yet even in Hitler Germany, the purification of the Aryan race was, apart from the Nuremberg Race Laws, at first sought to be achieved by a policy of mass migration, in particular to the liberal ‘Evian countries’. After the outbreak of war, with the occupation of France and the Netherlands, and other neighbouring countries with large Jewish minorities, this was replaced for new plans for forced migrations of European Jews to overseas colonies like Dutch Suriname (a plan proposed by NSB leader Mussert) and French Madagascar (v). These plans failed, however, because Britain kept control of the seas and the Germans could only rely on the continental railway system for executing deportations. But as Goebbels wrote in his diary in March 1942, it was the brutalization of war after the invasion in Soviet Russia, which offered “a whole series of possibilities [...] which would denied us in peace”.(xxxx) The Nazi policy of Jewish migration was by then replaced by the unexpected horizon of a politics of extermination.

data.title: Westerbork
data.description: The Westerbork camp in the Netherlands testifies to overlapping histories of politics of exclusion and inclusion. It was established in 1939, after the Dutch borders were closed down for refugees by the government, as a central refugee camp for Jews who fled from Germany and Anschluss Austria. In total, after Hitler’s ascent to power in 1933, almost 32,000 German Jews found refuge in the Netherlands, some 10,000 after the 1938 November or Kristallnacht pogroms. At the beginning of the German occupation in May 1940 it hosted only 750 refugees, but when the Nazis turned the refugee camp into a transit camp in July 1942 the camp was enlarged with new barracks for Dutch Jews. Already since February 1941 Dutch and German Jews were caught by Nazi raids (razzia’s) in the Amsterdam Judenviertel and in other cities, but from July 1942 until the beginning of the railway strike of September 1944 the Polizeiliches Judendurchgangslager Westerbork served that function. In close cooperation with the Amsterdam Jewish Council (Joodse Raad) at about 107,000 (of a total of 145,000 Dutch Jews), and 245 Sinti and Roma, of 97 transports were selected for weekly deportations to concentration and extermination camps in Germany and Eastern Europe, most of them to Auschwitz-Birkenau and Sobibor. The façade of a seemingly peaceful place where people waited in fear on the deadly transports was described in painful details by the Dutch journalist Philip Mechanicus in his camp diary In Depot and in the letters and diaries of Etty Hillesum, and filmed by the German-Jewish photographer Rudolf Breslauer for his 1944 Westerbork film, of which the footage (since 2017 registered as UNESCO Memory of the World) contains the only known real-life moving images of a Nazi train transport. Only 5,000 deportees survived the war. After Poland, the Germans were nowhere more successful in the extermination of Jews than in the Netherlands.  Yet the camp was controlled by only a few German SS officers, with help of some SS trained volunteers from German and Amsterdam police battalions and the Dutch Waffen SS, housed in the nearby SS camp Hooghalen, or Heidelager. The Dutch military police (Marechaussee) continued to guard the camp inside, assisted by a Jewish camp police. The latter, the OD (Ordnungsdienst), distinctive in their green overalls (since 1943) who had to help with the transports, garnered the worst reputation among Dutch Jewish inmates as the ‘Jewish SS’.  Westerbork underwent a new transformation after the liberation, when between 1945 and 1948 it came to serve as an internment camp for members of the Dutch National Socialist Party (NSB), SS volunteers and other people suspected of having collaborated with the Nazis. It also briefly served as a training base for soldiers during the Indonesian War of Independence  (1945-1949) and a camp for Dutch repatriates from the Dutch Indies. From 1951 to 1970 the camp, renamed Schattenberg, became the residence of a large part of former Moluccan soldiers of the Royal Netherlands East Indies Army  (KNIL) with their families, who left the island of Ambon after the Indonesian repression of their independence movement. Two decades after living in the camp, the Moluccans saw their camp demolished after the government approved the project of the Westerbork Synthesis Radio Telescope on the campscape. The Schattenberg community was relocated to surrounding villages. With the exception of the camp commander’s house and the 1949 Resistance Monument, the campscape was already half empty when in 1970 the National Monument Camp Westerbork was unveiled, and in 1983, three kilometres away from the silence zone, the Memorial Centre  Camp Westerbork was opened. From then on Jewish survivors held regular commemorations and the annual number of visitors rose constantly, reaching 180,000 in 2019. Since 2000 the Memorial Center has made room for research and presentations on the wider biography of the site, but confronted itself in 2008 with strong protests against its temporary exhibition of the NSB period, after which the museum and the “holy ground” of the campscape have become separated spaces, the latter mainly dedicated to Holocaust commemoration. Yet, within the current context of a growing competition of Holocaust and postcolonial memories, and the refugee issue, the memorialization of the various groups which went through Westerbork and Schattenberg, and their divergent experiences including the role of the perpetrators, remains contested up to today.

title: The KNIL Veterans and “national” heritage
credits: erasure, guilt, heroism, minority, militarism, postcolonialism

page_blocks.text: In 2014, an article in the press was capturing the conflict between two groups of veterans of the Dutch Army. The rights of those fighting in the KNIL (Dutch Army in the Colonies) were being contested by former members of the regular units of the Dutch Army. The latter contested the rights of the former to be recognized formally and to receive state pension. The debate was only part of the competing memories and disputations around the memory of colonialism, in which the Westerbork site has played a substantial part. The veterans of the KNIL, Moluccans from the southern islands of Indonesia, fought next to the Dutch colonial authorities until the end of the Indonesian Independence War. Part Dutch and loyal to the Dutch Crown from which they were expecting support for an independent republic, they agreed to the temporary plan of being evacuated to the Netherlands. In 1951, approximately 13000 former KNIL soldiers and families arrived in the country and were housed on the premises of the former concentration camps. Apart from Westerbork, now Schattenberg, others were housed in Kamp Vught (Lunetten). The somewhat paradoxical situation of placing anyone on the ground of the former camp was “utilitarian”, the organizing committee argued.

data.title: Commemoration KNIL in Schattenberg
data.description: The footage is a rare occasion when Moluccan KNIL veterans participate in the official commemorations of the victims of the war in 1956. A joined ceremony contrasts with the situation nowadays, when the Westerbork memorial organises separate commemorations on the former campsite. The difference shows the politics and the simmering conflicts around the integration of the Moluccan community. At the same time, this dynamics testifies to the evident tensions around the status of former KNIL soldiers within the broader public memory of the heroism of the Dutch army during the war. It is a situation that escalated through time, as was the case of the longstanding opposition of the Dutch government against granting the Moluccan soldiers state veteran pensions.

page_blocks.text:
Their stay in the camp was contradictory. On the one hand, the frugal lifestyle allowed for a feeling of temporariness that kept the political cause of the “homeland” vivid. For the Dutch government, the political promise was increasingly unlikely at the height of the de-colonial age , but there were still feelings of responsibility concerning the group. Their cause was rather looked at with sympathy.

They were considered part of the colonial fabric which had been taken away from the kingdom and consequently their military cause drew support in the midst of a radical change in the way citizens perceived the state. Moluccans however had an ambivalent civil status, with their citizenship being recognized only later. Due to differences of language, they were, for instance, not considered the equals of Dutch Indonesians also returning to the country in 1950.

page_blocks.text: Testimonies in the camp show how families were trying to maintain a semblance of normality for children who were growing up far from the homeland. Some integrated fast and went to work in the surrounding cities, like Assen. The camp was a temporary home where children learned the language, and adults were passing the time before hopefully returning to the islands. Initially isolated in the camp in Drenthe, some tried to find work in agriculture or private houses around the camp in order to supplement the little financial support offered by the government. The Dutch government also organized a school in Schattenberg, where children could learn the proper language. Some, with time, went to schools around the former camp.  At the same time, the arrival of the Moluccans in 1951 hightlighted how authority was built on differentiations between identities, based on nationality, religion, ethnicity, class, and gender. by exclusion and inclusion between various, newly performed categories of in- and outsiders, of established and newcomers, and of privileged and disenfranchised, are then part of the biography of this campscape, as similar to many others. From former subjects of the Dutch empire, they were evidently considered rather “second class” citizens, if citizens at all.

page_blocks.text:
But for the military heads of these families, the long wait and the condition of living in isolation proved to be quickly problematic. The memory of the war and of the service, which brought all categories together, did not last for more than a decade. The fact that the government rather tolerated, than cultivate the political cause of the Moluccans and therefore their military status, turned into a conflict. In Westerbork, conflicts started when they were asked to pay contributions as any other refugee and culminated in the forceful intervention in West Kapelle. The footage of the commemoration of the war, in 1956, 11 years after its end, on the former camp site of Westerbork is an opportunity to see, side by side, veterans of the Dutch Army (KL) and veterans of the Royal Netherlands East Indies Army (KNIL).

The camp had been transformed into a temporary shelter for the Moluccans, a group fighting together with the Dutch armies against the Indonesian independence. And yet, today the role of this community in the war is contested, also partly due to the expectations of Dutch support in securing an independent republic in the Moluccan islands. The commemorations in the camp are now separated, with the former Moluccan KNIL speaking little about the war, and the former KL contesting their role in the war. What larger implications do these debates hold?

data.title: Commemoration KNIL in Schattenberg
data.description: The footage is a rare occasion when Moluccan KNIL veterans participate in the official commemorations of the victims of the war in 1956. A joined ceremony contrasts with the situation nowadays, when the Westerbork memorial organises separate commemorations on the former campsite. The difference shows the politics and the simmering conflicts around the integration of the Moluccan community. At the same time, this dynamics testifies to the evident tensions around the status of former KNIL soldiers within the broader public memory of the heroism of the Dutch army during the war. It is a situation that escalated through time, as was the case of the longstanding opposition of the Dutch government against granting the Moluccan soldiers state veteran pensions.

page_blocks.text: The policy of little engagement with the community stirred the conflict. The Moluccans felt both isolated and their political cause neglected. In 1955, the government also changed the regulations for the state support of the group, which made daily life more difficult, without any real support for employment. Although the military status was something increasingly avoided by the government, the Moluccans were intrinsically linked to the teritoriaal bevelhebber (territorial commander) of North Holland, col. Piet van der Speck Obreen. taken prisoner or war during the Nazi occupation in the Netherlands, when the was imprisoned for 2 years in Stalag 371 Stanislau, Kamp Stanislau in Ukraine. Upon his return to the Netherlands, in 1947 he was in Indonesia. In 1951, he was stationed in the commander house, near Westerbork, soon to become woonoord Schattenberg for the Moluccan community.

Representing perpetrators through heritage

page_blocks.text: But the 1960s saw a continuous struggle to have the rights of those who had fought in the KNIL recognized. Newspapers show manifestations and large mobilizations around the issue. This social debate coincided on the one hand, with the radicalization of the Moluccan youth against the Dutch government. As the political prospects of an independent republic in the Moluccan islands was becoming evidently only an ideal, frictions emerged within the community, and between various generations. Some decided to return to Indonesia, others decided to stay on. The youth was equally divided, despite a broader integration in the society. On the other, there were broader complaints and requests coming from soldiers who had fought in the colonies and the way these were administered by the government. The uneasy status of de-colonization influenced much of how pensions and civil rights of former veterans were recognized and awarded.

data.title: Westerbork
data.description: The Westerbork camp in the Netherlands testifies to overlapping histories of politics of exclusion and inclusion. It was established in 1939, after the Dutch borders were closed down for refugees by the government, as a central refugee camp for Jews who fled from Germany and Anschluss Austria. In total, after Hitler’s ascent to power in 1933, almost 32,000 German Jews found refuge in the Netherlands, some 10,000 after the 1938 November or Kristallnacht pogroms. At the beginning of the German occupation in May 1940 it hosted only 750 refugees, but when the Nazis turned the refugee camp into a transit camp in July 1942 the camp was enlarged with new barracks for Dutch Jews. Already since February 1941 Dutch and German Jews were caught by Nazi raids (razzia’s) in the Amsterdam Judenviertel and in other cities, but from July 1942 until the beginning of the railway strike of September 1944 the Polizeiliches Judendurchgangslager Westerbork served that function. In close cooperation with the Amsterdam Jewish Council (Joodse Raad) at about 107,000 (of a total of 145,000 Dutch Jews), and 245 Sinti and Roma, of 97 transports were selected for weekly deportations to concentration and extermination camps in Germany and Eastern Europe, most of them to Auschwitz-Birkenau and Sobibor. The façade of a seemingly peaceful place where people waited in fear on the deadly transports was described in painful details by the Dutch journalist Philip Mechanicus in his camp diary In Depot and in the letters and diaries of Etty Hillesum, and filmed by the German-Jewish photographer Rudolf Breslauer for his 1944 Westerbork film, of which the footage (since 2017 registered as UNESCO Memory of the World) contains the only known real-life moving images of a Nazi train transport. Only 5,000 deportees survived the war. After Poland, the Germans were nowhere more successful in the extermination of Jews than in the Netherlands.  Yet the camp was controlled by only a few German SS officers, with help of some SS trained volunteers from German and Amsterdam police battalions and the Dutch Waffen SS, housed in the nearby SS camp Hooghalen, or Heidelager. The Dutch military police (Marechaussee) continued to guard the camp inside, assisted by a Jewish camp police. The latter, the OD (Ordnungsdienst), distinctive in their green overalls (since 1943) who had to help with the transports, garnered the worst reputation among Dutch Jewish inmates as the ‘Jewish SS’.  Westerbork underwent a new transformation after the liberation, when between 1945 and 1948 it came to serve as an internment camp for members of the Dutch National Socialist Party (NSB), SS volunteers and other people suspected of having collaborated with the Nazis. It also briefly served as a training base for soldiers during the Indonesian War of Independence  (1945-1949) and a camp for Dutch repatriates from the Dutch Indies. From 1951 to 1970 the camp, renamed Schattenberg, became the residence of a large part of former Moluccan soldiers of the Royal Netherlands East Indies Army  (KNIL) with their families, who left the island of Ambon after the Indonesian repression of their independence movement. Two decades after living in the camp, the Moluccans saw their camp demolished after the government approved the project of the Westerbork Synthesis Radio Telescope on the campscape. The Schattenberg community was relocated to surrounding villages. With the exception of the camp commander’s house and the 1949 Resistance Monument, the campscape was already half empty when in 1970 the National Monument Camp Westerbork was unveiled, and in 1983, three kilometres away from the silence zone, the Memorial Centre  Camp Westerbork was opened. From then on Jewish survivors held regular commemorations and the annual number of visitors rose constantly, reaching 180,000 in 2019. Since 2000 the Memorial Center has made room for research and presentations on the wider biography of the site, but confronted itself in 2008 with strong protests against its temporary exhibition of the NSB period, after which the museum and the “holy ground” of the campscape have become separated spaces, the latter mainly dedicated to Holocaust commemoration. Yet, within the current context of a growing competition of Holocaust and postcolonial memories, and the refugee issue, the memorialization of the various groups which went through Westerbork and Schattenberg, and their divergent experiences including the role of the perpetrators, remains contested up to today.

title: The postcolonial “blankspot”
credits: genocide, historical justice, postcolonialism, recognition, resource, silencing, victimhood

page_blocks.text: In 2018, the final ruling in a long trial against the Dutch government rules the two soldiers in the Dutch Army and implicitly the state did not make use of “extraordinary means of violence” against the Moluccan group. The trial was the latest legal reaction to the the military intervention of the government in 1977, when a group of young Moluccans hijacked a train between Assen and Groningen. It was the fourth such type of action demanding the the support of the government for the independent republic of Moluccan Islands. It turned however into a divisive political debate and memorial concern when two of the hostages were killed. The intervention of the Dutch troops resulted in the death of six of the hijackers. The debate in the recent trial was whether the intervention en force had indeed been necessary and whether the victims were not an unncessary consequence of the use of force. It was a tense moment, which was also amply speculated by the fact that Parliamentary elections were being held at the time. The prime-minister was among the first on site and the intervention was covered live. Images around that intervention resonated for many with pictures taking during evacuation of the Moluccan communities from the “temporary” accommodations, like Westerbork. The story had been equally controversial then, with the Moluccans refusing to leave and police force being employed on the grounds of the camp, pushing this “postcolonial” issue firmly into public debate.

page_blocks.text:
The story of the Indonesian repatriates and Moluccan KNIL soldiers who lived in the same barracks for two decades after the war were an aftethought of the Indonesian War on Independence which might have gotten lost in the efforts of “reconstruction” post-war but scarred public, political and social debate up to now. In the Netherlands, the Moluccans were housed in camps – most socially and physically isolated from Dutch society – where the Dutch government looked after their basic necessities. Men were discharged from the army upon, or just before, arrival and not, as they felt entitled to, in accordance with the military charter of the KNIL in their own Moluccas. This caused
a sharp conflict between the Moluccans and the Dutch government. Attempts to fight the discharge in court failed for procedural reasons. Deep mistrust and resentment resulted among the Moluccans.

On the other hand,  the decolonisation, which refers to
Indonesia (1949) and Surinam (1975) changed a landscape which, right after the war, in 1947, only counted about 104,000 individuals with a foreign nationality, that is 1 % of the population. Following Indonesia,  large numbers of Eurasian repatriates who had been interned in the Japanese camps in the Dutch East Indies/ Indonesia during the War returned home. Migration from Indonesia has caused no economic problems for migrants with Dutch citizenship (which they possessed in case of two Dutch parents, and could choose in case of one Dutch parent) and apparently, integration has been smooth. But the position of Moluccans,  concentrated in certain areas in the Netherlands, isolated and seen to be deliberately declining integration, hoping to return to an independent Moluccan republic, caused difficulties. Up until the mid-1970s
they were convinced that they would return to a re-established RMS.
Reluctantly integrating into Dutch society caused tensions on both sides.

The train hijacking of 1977 has been since considered a trauma, of both an seeming “excessive” way of making political claims and perhaps a too unsensitive position of the Dutch government concerning the long, rather than short process of integrating and coming to terms with its own “postcolonial” condition. Integration was not a failed project for most, but by the 1970s, many of the Moluccan community had returned to Indonesia. Despite the political dissonances and differences of opinion concerning the political position of the community in the Netherlands, however, the hijackings were equally prompted by ambigous positions against those in the country, like for instance in West Capelle. That forceful intervention of the government came at a time when issues of rights of this temporary group who was nevertheless an integral part of the Dutch larger society and of debates about the path of social democracy in front wider changes coming from opening borders and massive immigration to the Netherlands.

page_blocks.text:
There was a contemporary dynamics to the memory of colonialism. Integration in Dutch society had a direct relation to the mass emigration post-war. The heroic memory of the military overshadowed the past colonial history. 

The relative isolation of Moluccans continued until the mid-1960s, even though the Dutch government curtailed their living allowances after 1956, forcing them to look for jobs. In 1956, for example, central services in the camps were stopped. In the 1960s, most of the camps were broken up and their residents were housed in special quarters within villages and small towns. While still living in one of the 60 camps (the number changed over time), a whole range of associations and institutions was established, varying from churches and sports clubs to societies based on villages or islands of origin known as kumpulan. Each camp had a council representing the interests of its inhabitants vis-à-vis the Dutch government and its representatives. These Moluccan institutions were local, but were presided over by national boards. There were conflicts and schisms among the organisations and churches. Supporters of rivalling ones were housed in different camps. The result was that in 1953, the Moluccan camps (which were spread all over the country) formed a kind of Moluccan archipelago. Some of the camps were linked to each other by interest organisations and churches, but almost all were linked by the kumpulan, which were not influenced by politics.

page_blocks.text:
Moluccans considered provision of housing and subsistence allowances to be a token from the Dutch government who felt a responsibility towards them in their status as exiles. Within a few years of their arrival, however, an increasing number of Moluccans found work on the labour market. For that reason, the Dutch government curtailed its subsistence allowances. Moluccan leaders sharply reproached the Dutch government for neglecting its true responsibility to them as exiles. Meanwhile, they exerted tight
social control over their rank and file, to ensure that the RMS ideal was upheld.

 As the situation changed in Indonesia in the 1960s, the RMS movement in the Netherlands transformed from a nationalistic support movement into an ex-patria nationalistic movement: Moluccans in the Netherlands were convinced that they had to liberate the Moluccas working from the outside. Consequently, the second generation found its inspiration in movements such as the Black Panthers in the United States and the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, as well as in Castro’s Cuba. Inspired by the spirit of the 1960s and the civil rights movement, the Moluccan youngsters turned to radical political responses.  Inspired by the ‘black is beautiful’ movement, they took a provocative attitude towards Dutch society, travelling around the country in large groups. This quite often resulted in fights and confrontations with local youths.
Some Moluccan youngsters became involved in criminal activities, robbing
banks or selling drugs to raise money for ‘the struggle’, as it was called. From the
mid-1960s onwards, young Moluccan activists from all over the Netherlands met and entered into discussions, overcoming the many political divides among existing Moluccan organisations. Young Moluccans started to study Dutch colonial history, the
role and position of the Moluccan Islands and particularly of Moluccans in that history. They immersed themselves in the history of social and political movements and with classic works in the field, such as those by Franz Fanon and Karl Marx. 

It is partly why the verdict in 2018 has been amply contested, just as much as the reaction in 1977 was contested by a great deal of public opinion. Many considered it a justified political cause left unaddressed for too long by the government. There were shows of solidarity with the protesters across Europe. Official reactions from the government showed however outrage, a sense of betrayal for what had been a temporary solutions meant to also protect the former KNIL soldiers from the new Indonesian authorities who would have held them accountable for what essentially would have been considered a “collaboration” with the colonial authorities. In the aftermath of the intervention, newspapers were discussing the problematic position on past colonialism and an unreflexive look at the past as the underlying debate of the situation.

data.title: Bitter Spice: Indonesia and the Netherlands from 1600
data.author: Stevens, Harm
data.titleOfBookOrArticle: Bitter Spice: Indonesia and the Netherlands from 1600

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: The postcolonial “blankspot”

page_blocks.text:
Indeed, the memory of colonialism has been a late comer but a fiercely debate topic when it did. It remains a topic often veiled in nostalgia, despitely the “negative” history it equally is reminiscent of. The Moluccan Islands were in fact the centre of a fierce resource competition between the Portuguese crown and the Dutch East India Company (VOC) in the 17th century, due to the wealth of spice. The VOC was so interested in the nutmeg plantations in the island that at the middle of the century the population of the island (Moluccans) were a “collateral” damage to the industry.

But in parallel, another development was the growing awareness of social problems
within the Moluccan community. For a long time, unemployment was not seen as a problem by Moluccans because they were not meant to become a part of Dutch society. However, in the course of the 1970s, unemployment became a serious problem. Dutch social work institutions seemed incapable of helping Moluccans. From 1976 on, this led to an increasing number of Moluccan initiatives to deal with the problems within their community. Like the political discussion on reformulating the RMS ideal and the visits to the Moluccas, the ‘discovery’ of social problems resulted in a minimised emphasis on the RMS. Many people who were politically active in earlier years could be found in the emerging Moluccan social work initiatives. Some of them combined their activities in social work projects (such as drug aid) with organising political courses, but they were no longer rigidly oriented towards the RMS ideal. A large group of young Moluccans entered academic programmes for social work, called ‘second-chance education’ for people who had dropped out of school.

The hijackings was another defining moment in the relationship between Moluccan immigrants and Dutch society at large. This was an agreement between the Moluccans and the Dutch government made in 1986. Its prelude was a growing dissatisfaction about the condition of housing in specific Moluccan quarters, most of which were built
hastily by the Dutch government or housing cooperatives in the 1960s and
was in bad shape by the 1980s. During the tense 1970s, some housing cooperations and the Dutch government had not raised house rents in Moluccan wards. In the 1980s, they nevertheless decided to bring rents up to par with the normal level in the Netherlands, though without improving the housing’s poor quality. Inhabitants often refused to pay rent. Efforts to evict these tenants in January 1984 led to battles and
police had to draw guns. Again, tensions between Moluccans and Dutch authorities increased and once more, the issue became political. Moluccan spokesmen pointed out that the Dutch government had brought Moluccan soldiers to the Netherlands and therefore were responsible for providing proper housing. They explicitly used the term ‘KNIL-rechten’ (‘the rights of KNIL soldiers’).  The housing dispute coincided with a major change in Dutch government policy towards ethnic minorities. From the 1950s onwards, this policy was focused on establishing specific ethnic-based facilities under the so-called ‘group-oriented approach’.  When, however, in the 1970s the Netherlands became an immigration country and other groups came to the country (such as Moroccans), the government wanted to abandon the group-oriented approach. It was too expensive and considered an obstruction to integration.

data.title: Westerbork
data.description: The Westerbork camp in the Netherlands testifies to overlapping histories of politics of exclusion and inclusion. It was established in 1939, after the Dutch borders were closed down for refugees by the government, as a central refugee camp for Jews who fled from Germany and Anschluss Austria. In total, after Hitler’s ascent to power in 1933, almost 32,000 German Jews found refuge in the Netherlands, some 10,000 after the 1938 November or Kristallnacht pogroms. At the beginning of the German occupation in May 1940 it hosted only 750 refugees, but when the Nazis turned the refugee camp into a transit camp in July 1942 the camp was enlarged with new barracks for Dutch Jews. Already since February 1941 Dutch and German Jews were caught by Nazi raids (razzia’s) in the Amsterdam Judenviertel and in other cities, but from July 1942 until the beginning of the railway strike of September 1944 the Polizeiliches Judendurchgangslager Westerbork served that function. In close cooperation with the Amsterdam Jewish Council (Joodse Raad) at about 107,000 (of a total of 145,000 Dutch Jews), and 245 Sinti and Roma, of 97 transports were selected for weekly deportations to concentration and extermination camps in Germany and Eastern Europe, most of them to Auschwitz-Birkenau and Sobibor. The façade of a seemingly peaceful place where people waited in fear on the deadly transports was described in painful details by the Dutch journalist Philip Mechanicus in his camp diary In Depot and in the letters and diaries of Etty Hillesum, and filmed by the German-Jewish photographer Rudolf Breslauer for his 1944 Westerbork film, of which the footage (since 2017 registered as UNESCO Memory of the World) contains the only known real-life moving images of a Nazi train transport. Only 5,000 deportees survived the war. After Poland, the Germans were nowhere more successful in the extermination of Jews than in the Netherlands.  Yet the camp was controlled by only a few German SS officers, with help of some SS trained volunteers from German and Amsterdam police battalions and the Dutch Waffen SS, housed in the nearby SS camp Hooghalen, or Heidelager. The Dutch military police (Marechaussee) continued to guard the camp inside, assisted by a Jewish camp police. The latter, the OD (Ordnungsdienst), distinctive in their green overalls (since 1943) who had to help with the transports, garnered the worst reputation among Dutch Jewish inmates as the ‘Jewish SS’.  Westerbork underwent a new transformation after the liberation, when between 1945 and 1948 it came to serve as an internment camp for members of the Dutch National Socialist Party (NSB), SS volunteers and other people suspected of having collaborated with the Nazis. It also briefly served as a training base for soldiers during the Indonesian War of Independence  (1945-1949) and a camp for Dutch repatriates from the Dutch Indies. From 1951 to 1970 the camp, renamed Schattenberg, became the residence of a large part of former Moluccan soldiers of the Royal Netherlands East Indies Army  (KNIL) with their families, who left the island of Ambon after the Indonesian repression of their independence movement. Two decades after living in the camp, the Moluccans saw their camp demolished after the government approved the project of the Westerbork Synthesis Radio Telescope on the campscape. The Schattenberg community was relocated to surrounding villages. With the exception of the camp commander’s house and the 1949 Resistance Monument, the campscape was already half empty when in 1970 the National Monument Camp Westerbork was unveiled, and in 1983, three kilometres away from the silence zone, the Memorial Centre  Camp Westerbork was opened. From then on Jewish survivors held regular commemorations and the annual number of visitors rose constantly, reaching 180,000 in 2019. Since 2000 the Memorial Center has made room for research and presentations on the wider biography of the site, but confronted itself in 2008 with strong protests against its temporary exhibition of the NSB period, after which the museum and the “holy ground” of the campscape have become separated spaces, the latter mainly dedicated to Holocaust commemoration. Yet, within the current context of a growing competition of Holocaust and postcolonial memories, and the refugee issue, the memorialization of the various groups which went through Westerbork and Schattenberg, and their divergent experiences including the role of the perpetrators, remains contested up to today.

title: Representing perpetrators through heritage
credits: collaboration, human rights, perpetrators, silence, socialism/communism, victimhood

page_blocks.text: In 2015, the Dutch curator Erik Schilp in the daily Dutch De Volkskrant was calling the new glass case that the Westerbork memorial placed over the Commander House “expensive and unnecessary”. He argued that it is not in itself representative of the history of the camp and should only distract visitors from its main story about the victims of the Holocaust as symbolised by Ralph Prince’s National Monument and the monument of the 102.000 stones. The memorial argued, however, that these were designed as memorials, whereas the house is one of the few remaining authentic remnants of the disappeared camp. It was developed from the start as an integral part of the 1939 plan of the Central Refugee Camp. After the camp turned into a transit camp for Dutch Jews in 1942, the director’s home became the seat of the Nazi-German camp commander Albert Gemmeker and his secretary and mistress Elisabeth Hassler. They both played an important role in the many transmitted memories of inmates, whose experience and fate in (and after) the camp were decided from this perpetrator space. Slanted to the main road of the camp, which in 1942 turned into a railway platform, the commander had a panoptic view on the railway platform. From the balcony of his office on the first floor he could monitor the arriving trains from Amsterdam and the Nazi-German concentrations camps Vught and Amersfoort, and the departing trains to the eastern concentration and extermination camps Auschwitz, Sobibor, Theresienstadt and Bergen-Belsen.

data.title: The “Commander House” in Westerbork, the Netherlands
data.description: Walking on the Westerbork site today, the “commander house” is the most visible element and also the one structure which has never been removed, revamped or torn down in the successive interventions on the site. It sits under a glass case, as a particularly precious exhibit. All camp commanders after 1941 inhabited the house, including the name indelibly linked to the Westerbork camp, Albert Konrad Gemmeker. After the war, the house was linked to the colonial history of the Netherlands, through col. Van der Speck O’Breen, a former officer in the Dutch Army in Indonesia who, as the new territorial commander, was assigned duties concerning the temporary habitation of the Moluccan group. Initially built by day wagers, many of them Jewish refugees, working to survive in Drenthe, the house is historically significant for the rights, exclusion and perception of refugees in the Netherlands and how the regime of detention for protection gradually turned into a space of concentration and the Holocaust. A symbol of power for most living in the nearby camp, before, during and after the war, it was a vehicle of a spatial organisation of power and hierarchy by means of demarcations. All through the existence of any form of camp, it spoke about a process of denationalization or statelessness for refugees, inmates and the temporary inhabitants of Schattenberg. It was inevitably a space of power for the various individuals who lived in the camp. Inmates in the camp would refer to it as the “outside”. These connotations reinforced the oppositions which make a camp: between “citizens” and “strangers”, “natives” and “migrants”, “residents” and “occupiers”. The story of the former “Commander’s” house tells us a lot about the physical existence designated who was an inmate and who held authority and how. What are the implications of memorialization when the most visible element on the site is the “the heritage” of power and the perpetrator?

page_blocks.text:
Yet for more than sixty years after the end of the war, the former commander house had an independent biography from the camp. Its last inhabitant was the daughter of the late territorial commander of the Northern Netherlands, Colonel Piet van der Speck Obreen, who took residency with his wife and two daughters in 1950, when Westerbork functioned shortly as a military training site. Recently returned from the Dutch Indies, which soon before had become independent after three years of violent decolonization wars, the colonel was posted in the house next to the camp which was then renamed Schattenberg. The former Jewish refugee and transit camp had already been reused to function as a temporary housing for the Moluccan veterans with their families of the KNIL. Although in no formal relation to Schattenberg, his military past and his present position made him partly responsible for the life of the Moluccan community far from Indonesia. He retired as a commandable example of authority in the area.

But the Camp Westerbork memorial center has recently received its European heritage label because of its functioning as a memorial site of the Second World War. Westerbork is not only relevant to the Dutch Jewish community, but the location symbolizes a collective memory among Jewish survivor communities all over the world. Furthermore, as a "European heritage site" is brings forward a transnational symbolism of the Holocaust as a history which should be prevented from repeating, embodied by the phrase "never again".  

The symbolism of Westerbork as a space of educational remembrance is particularly linked with that of perpetratorship also by different heritages. The Westerbork film, for instance,  commissioned by Albert Gemmeker, the commander of the camp, remains a singular testimony of the life inside a concentration camp, where one sees also the absurd facade of an efficient, functional life in imprisonment which made transports seem to be naturally blended in the background.   Even though the (probably) unfinished film was meant for propaganda, the 90 minutes footage offers today the only contemporary visual testimony of a Holocaust campscape. Filmed by an experienced Jewish filmmaker the also still existing script offered enough space to go beyond the staged appearance of the few other, comparable propaganda movies, such as Kurt Gerron’s Theresiënstadt.

data.title: Westerbork film (produced by Rudolf Breslauer)
data.description: By order of camp commandant Albert Konrad Gemmeker, the photographer and Jewish prisoner of Westerbork Rudolf Breslauer produced in 1944 a film of the daily life in camp including deportations to concentration camps in the East. After the war Gemmeker said the aim of the film was to create a memory of this time. But it also showed aspects of work and production in the camp and thus gave the impression that Westerbork - and Gemmeker's position as well - are worth to maintain.

page_blocks.text: The reason why the commander house in Westerbork was embroiled in a debate about its status 70 years after the end of the war has also to do with the diffuse and sometime benign perspective that the house had projected. It was in this context that the switch from the house as a private property to a space of heritage opened a wide aray of questions about the significance of the site, what narrative should be memorialized on site and whether a heritage of the perpetrator, which seemed at times to go against the interest of the victims, is desirable. Westerbork is a late comer of sorts to a debate which speaks about the dynamics of the memory of the Holocaust, and the focus on the victim. Indeed, the heritage site as it looks today is almost exclusively evocative of the latter, and in particular of Jewish victims of the transports. It conveys a larger dynamics about what and how we choose to remember.

page_blocks.text:
Representing and coupling heritage with perpetratorship is a bit of a turn in the idea of “politics of regret” (Olick 2007) that for the better part of the last four decades have spoken about victims only. Initially sidelined in a few important and mediatized cases (like the trial in Nuremberg, the Auschwitz trial, the Eichmann trial), that played in fact in the anti-fascist narrative of memory which helped both the Eastern European communism and the Western European social democracy to stabilize (Rethinking Antifascism: History, Memory and Politics, 1922 to the Present, 2016), with the rise of the memory of the Holocaust by the 1970s the discussion was almost exclusively focused on the victims (Levy, Szaider 2010).

Perspectives on the perpetrators have changed dramatically over the decades that have passed:Yet, the fierce debates surrounding the publication of Jonathan Littell’s novel Les Bienveillantes in 2006, a fictional memoir of an SS-officer, a number of other cultural productions returned the gaze to the perpetrator. At times, this angle retraced the complex motivations and a gray type of historical writing which had been popular earlier, but it also asked questions about what a history exclusively told through victimhood constructs. It exposed a central tension in public and academic conceptions of witnessing and the Holocaust: letting the victim speak only about its own trauma or making the victim be a warden of war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocides. Paradoxically, the interest in the perpetrators emerged with a growing historiography which shows the pitfalls of the generalization of victimhood, the disturbing vindication of said condition on behalf of those responsible, the ever-more abundant participation of ordinary perpetrators in massacres or, on occasions, the fragile border that separates victim and aggressor.

page_blocks.text: The heritage of the perpetrator however inevitably maintains alive a memory of injustice, rather than reconciliation, of half said truths or of justice attempts which were only pure expressions of the time, lin the same vein as the “forced confrontations” had been at the end of the war for denazification. Indeed, at the end of the war, the polics of “dead bodied” was an instrument of memory as much as of education, of sorts. But this connection has been easy ever since, primariy because it changed the idea that heritage is necessarily triumphant or glorious. If heritage is always about identity, than inscribing the perpetrator into heritage shows a “negative” side of this identity, a lack or a pitfall. Often, as in the case of other trials at the end of the war, for instance Hanns Albin Rauter, they were discussed and positioned as an external element to the “nation” and the country. The war in this case, and the biography of Gemmeker inscripts a perpetrator who, a foreigner and a product of an “exceptionalist” German regime, speaks little about the local context. Were we indeed to zoom out of the history of the house and its meaning as heritage of perpetratorship, this angle would make it evocative of the type of power dynamics, abuse and subjectification happening equally during the refugee during the war, the house is also a good reminder of how power works through fragmenting and compartmentalized rulers and powerless, of “perpetrators” and “victims”. During the refugee period, its physical existence designated who was an inmate and who held authority. These connotations reinforced the oppositions which makes a camp: between “citizens” and “strangers”, “natives” and “migrants”. It was a space of demarcation involving state institutions and collaboration.

page_blocks.text: There has been an ample historical attention on the perpetrators in the Netherlands. this inchoate debate, there have been attempts to discuss and understand for instance the role and the motivation of Albert Konrad Gemmeker, the last commander of Westerbork . Described as a “gentleman”, his character was probed extensively after the war, more so than his deeds. The trial after the war and the short sentence were however an accurate map of the debates on what a memory of perpetratorship should serve: reconstruction, localizing the perpetrator and moving on, rather than dwelling on the past. Identifying the perpetrator as “German” was a side of the debate, fuelling in fact much of the selectivity of the history ever since. Their histories are infinitely more complex. For instance, the first commander of Westerbork, Erich Deppner, working in the Sicherheitspolizei in the Hague, has all chances of being held accountable after the war as evidence against him was mounting. The direct adjuct of Hanns Albin Rauter, in Camp Amersfoort, Deppner was responsble for mass shootings and murders of hundreds of Russian and German war prisoners. Testimonies from Westerbork speak about a ruthless person who coordinated the first transports. For his “achievements” he was transferred as commander in Kamp Vught, also in the Netherlands,where he was responsble, again, for at least 500 executions and a ruthless regime of the facility. Towards the end of the war, Deppner was transferred again to Germany and despite the waves of trials immediately after the war and a new momentum of transitional justice which swept Germany at the end of the 1950s and beginning of the 1960s, Deppner never appeared in a court of law. In 1964, the German authorities re-opened the case against AK Gemmeker, who suggests in an interview at the time that he is no way to be held responsible, and the he did not know what the transports and the destinations of these were. Despite the large uproar also in the Netherlands, he was sentenced to only two years of prison. Deppner, who by that time had ascended from the ranks of the Organization Gehlen to the German BND (the West German Secret Service) was never even questioned.

title: The trace of the political Left
credits: socialism/communism, heroism, perpetratorship, POWs, resistance, silencing

page_blocks.text:
In 2010, historian Timothy Snyder published an opinion piece in the Guardian under the title “the Reich’s forgotten atrocity”, rightfully pointing to the paradoxical extent to which Russian prisoners of war and war damages during operation Barbarossa, are forgotten. His article was met then with a sceptical eye by the European press, given what seemed to be a sympathetic eye towards Russia, but that scepticism was exactly the direction the American historian was pointing at. The issue of destruction and death in the East had been so ideologized in the decades that followed the war, by both “East” and “West”, that its history has been increasingly sidelined. Snyder has since been responsible from disentangling the history of the Holocaust in the still underinvestigated dimension of the war in Eastern Europe. Since 2008, the concern with “Stalin’s victims” has also become a more visible direction in public debate and historiography.

But, between these two diverging histories and a deep endurance of Cold War discourses, the focus on the “victims of “totalitarianism” have silenced the early history of the political left, its oppositional history before the war and its instrumental role in the of the wartime resistance.

data.title: The Reich's forgotten atrocity, by Timothy Snyder

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: The trace of the political Left

page_blocks.text:
There have been competing discourses on the issue for decades. At the height of the Cold War, former communists active during the war were an easy image to appropriate for socialist regimes (although they were equally selectively erased and silenced at the same time). On the other side of the “Iron Curtain”, those in the “West” were negotiating their sometimes difficult position in relation to the USSR, in particular in spaces where the socialist and communist parties emerged as credible political options out of war, like in France.

All through Europe however, the memory of the heroic “anti-fascism” of the early postwar days was by the end of the 1960s diverging into memory conflicts. In Western Germany, the memory of the war was instrumental in the wide range of socialist claims launched at the end of the 1960s. In Eastern Europe, the socialist internationalism was changing as well, leaving behind the victims of the war and a canonical idea of resistance. The early contribution of the left as an opposition movement was subsiding.

page_blocks.text: Westerbork is a place for this history is crucial. Obviously, among those many fleeing Germany in 1933 to the Netherlands, there were those who had seen that the first victims of the political purges in the country had been those on the left. The KPD, the communist party in Germany, member of the Komintern (the Communist International) had been since 1918, a strong political force, and the hinge of the capitalist discourse on the nation of the NSDAP (National Socialists). When the KPD was banned as organization, leaders and most of its members were the first to be sent to concentrantion camps: in Dachau, Buchenwald etc.

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: The trace of the political Left

page_blocks.text: The histories from Westerbork speak little about the political activity and the various political positions in the camp, but more those who were there or survived it, it was a daily reality in the camp. Many of these were not for the first time in prison. The testimony of AN shows that his stay in Westerbork in the refugee camp followed in fact a period of detention in Nieuwersluis due to his communist sympathies. Foreigners (vreemdelingen) in the country and politically outspoken, two social behaviours which contradicted the laws in place allowing individuals to seek shelter in the Netherlands, those who spread propaganda material were actively imprisoned.

page_blocks.text: There were also those openly joining the left in the over 25 camps of refugees which existed prior to the establishment of the central refugee camp in Drenthe.  Westerbork was part of this history as it was intended to concentrate the “illegal” part of around 30.000 German refugees in the Netherlands. The governmental control over the communists and social democrats increased after 1934, making those in this situation directly dependent on the non-governmental system of support, which was particularly strong due to the “pillarized” social system of the Netherlands at the time (III), dividing social institutions along confessional and political lines.  Socialist groups enjoyed a strong social, cultural and political infrastructure, financially and institutionally.

data.title: Werkampen in Drenthe
data.description: Numerous workcamps existed in Drenthe prior to the war, primarily for employment  during the economic crisis. Many of these men were refugees and ended up in Westerbork

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: The trace of the political Left
The ambivalent memory of state involvement in Westerbork

page_blocks.text:
But despite the relative support infrastructure, those oriented towards the left were just as threatening as those veering to the right for the conservative political coalition in power, a christian and liberal mix. Communists were pursued as a threat to the stability of the country and interned in the increasing number of facilities: Fort Honswijk, for instance, which was also the focus was of a widespread protest in 1935 against the policy by the Rode Hulp (Red Support), next to Nieuwersluis, Bergen op Zoom, Breda, Maastricht, Tilburg and Vlissingen. The issue was so stringent for the government that also those who returned from fighting in the civil war in Spain, communists and social democrats alike, were imprisoned in Nieuwersluis, in Utrecht.

Even if such camps closed, many among those considered dangerous were still imprisoned, for instance in regular prisons. It did not mean however they were looked at with less suspicion. In fact, those returning from Spain lost citizenship status. This fear of social disruption endured and was aggravated by the February 1941 strike of factory workers after the first round-up of the Jewish Community in Amsterdam. Catalyzed by the Dutch Communist Party, it led to German retaliations and massive deportations of participants to Germany as political prisoners.

page_blocks.text: Werner Sterzenbach, an early communist in Deutsch-jϋdischer Wanderbund 'Kameraden' who fled Germany in 1933 and joined in Dutch communist circles and later the resistance. A Jew, he first ended up in the prison of Nieuwersluis because he was an anti-Zionist (against the predominant encouragement of emigration of the Dutch state) at a time when the government actively encouraged emigration of the Jewish community. As resistance member he was actively involved in the oppositional groups in Westerbork. He was one of the first prisoners in the camp and with technical experience he was, by the time the camp became functional, one of those doing maintenance work on the water facility. Through here he managed to help many escape the camp. His attempts were in fact well known in the camp.

data.title: Philip Mechanicus’ account on daily life in Westerbork, 3 June/14 August, 1943.
data.description: Philip Mechanicus, a Dutch Jewish journalist. During the German occupation, Mechanicus went into hiding, he was betrayed and arrested in 1942. On 7 November, he was brought to Westerbork, from where he was sent to Bergen-Belsen and Auschwitz-Birkenau, where he was executed in October 1944. Throughout his internment in Westerbork, Mechanicus kept a diary, which was published in 1964.
data.provenance: Source: Philip Mechanicus, Waiting for Death: A Diary, Calder and Boyars (London 1968), 30-32 and 129-130. June 3rd and August 14th, 1943.

page_blocks.text:
After May 1940, such disruptions were directly hindering the plan of Nazification and the integration of the Dutch economy in the German economy. The communists had a prominent role in the resistance in Westerbork and many managed to escape and go into hiding. The communist underground, made out of the many illegals who had either escaped from the prisons or were actively released through various pressures against the politics of the government.

These individuals made the first efforts to document the occupation, to gather incriminatory material presumably useful at the end. Werner Sterzenbach himself was one of the first people to be released, shortly after May 1945, a plea to reckon with perpetrators and collaborators. Sterzenbach published his journal from the camp, Rood en Jood (Red and Jewish) after the war as he was making his way back into the political life of Germany, where he finally returned. He comments here on the attempts of post-war accountability which often avoided members of the communist resistance. He continued in fact to be a vocal political actor in Germany writing about the responsibility and accountability of the perpetrators.
