data.title: Westerbork
data.description: The Westerbork camp in the Netherlands testifies to overlapping histories of politics of exclusion and inclusion. It was established in 1939, after the Dutch borders were closed down for refugees by the government, as a central refugee camp for Jews who fled from Germany and Anschluss Austria. In total, after Hitler’s ascent to power in 1933, almost 32,000 German Jews found refuge in the Netherlands, some 10,000 after the 1938 November or Kristallnacht pogroms. At the beginning of the German occupation in May 1940 it hosted only 750 refugees, but when the Nazis turned the refugee camp into a transit camp in July 1942 the camp was enlarged with new barracks for Dutch Jews. Already since February 1941 Dutch and German Jews were caught by Nazi raids (razzia’s) in the Amsterdam Judenviertel and in other cities, but from July 1942 until the beginning of the railway strike of September 1944 the Polizeiliches Judendurchgangslager Westerbork served that function. In close cooperation with the Amsterdam Jewish Council (Joodse Raad) at about 107,000 (of a total of 145,000 Dutch Jews), and 245 Sinti and Roma, of 97 transports were selected for weekly deportations to concentration and extermination camps in Germany and Eastern Europe, most of them to Auschwitz-Birkenau and Sobibor. The façade of a seemingly peaceful place where people waited in fear on the deadly transports was described in painful details by the Dutch journalist Philip Mechanicus in his camp diary In Depot and in the letters and diaries of Etty Hillesum, and filmed by the German-Jewish photographer Rudolf Breslauer for his 1944 Westerbork film, of which the footage (since 2017 registered as UNESCO Memory of the World) contains the only known real-life moving images of a Nazi train transport. Only 5,000 deportees survived the war. After Poland, the Germans were nowhere more successful in the extermination of Jews than in the Netherlands.  Yet the camp was controlled by only a few German SS officers, with help of some SS trained volunteers from German and Amsterdam police battalions and the Dutch Waffen SS, housed in the nearby SS camp Hooghalen, or Heidelager. The Dutch military police (Marechaussee) continued to guard the camp inside, assisted by a Jewish camp police. The latter, the OD (Ordnungsdienst), distinctive in their green overalls (since 1943) who had to help with the transports, garnered the worst reputation among Dutch Jewish inmates as the ‘Jewish SS’.  Westerbork underwent a new transformation after the liberation, when between 1945 and 1948 it came to serve as an internment camp for members of the Dutch National Socialist Party (NSB), SS volunteers and other people suspected of having collaborated with the Nazis. It also briefly served as a training base for soldiers during the Indonesian War of Independence  (1945-1949) and a camp for Dutch repatriates from the Dutch Indies. From 1951 to 1970 the camp, renamed Schattenberg, became the residence of a large part of former Moluccan soldiers of the Royal Netherlands East Indies Army  (KNIL) with their families, who left the island of Ambon after the Indonesian repression of their independence movement. Two decades after living in the camp, the Moluccans saw their camp demolished after the government approved the project of the Westerbork Synthesis Radio Telescope on the campscape. The Schattenberg community was relocated to surrounding villages. With the exception of the camp commander’s house and the 1949 Resistance Monument, the campscape was already half empty when in 1970 the National Monument Camp Westerbork was unveiled, and in 1983, three kilometres away from the silence zone, the Memorial Centre  Camp Westerbork was opened. From then on Jewish survivors held regular commemorations and the annual number of visitors rose constantly, reaching 180,000 in 2019. Since 2000 the Memorial Center has made room for research and presentations on the wider biography of the site, but confronted itself in 2008 with strong protests against its temporary exhibition of the NSB period, after which the museum and the “holy ground” of the campscape have become separated spaces, the latter mainly dedicated to Holocaust commemoration. Yet, within the current context of a growing competition of Holocaust and postcolonial memories, and the refugee issue, the memorialization of the various groups which went through Westerbork and Schattenberg, and their divergent experiences including the role of the perpetrators, remains contested up to today.

title: Dynamics of the Jewish memory of resistance around Westerbork
credits: antisemitism, collaboration, heroism, inclusion, integration, resistance

page_blocks.text: In 1979, the report on the wartime activities of Friedrich Weinreb issued by RIOD in Amsterdam was atypical. The claim of Weinreb, who claimed resistance during the war, was de-constructed not only as a means of pecuniary gain from those on their way to be deported, but as a self servicing moral issue, conveying the extent to which remembrance fixated on the binary relation between collaboration and resistance. Post-war claims that Jews had heroically resisted the Nazis on a large scale, and that even if not every Jew had engaged the enemy in direct combat, had been prevalent in the angle that also emphasized the support of the non-Jewish community. Indeed, the Jewish debate was at least problematic for the myth of the resistance, something evident also during the unveiling of the monument itself, when the mayor of Amsterdam at the time referenced “pride, but also shame”. The fact that the institutions needed to come with a public clarification concerning the actions of the Jewish community (which did not make then the government directly illustrative of a “national” politics of memory) was illustrative of the contemporary politics of memory concerning the resistance.

data.title: Report of the NIOD concerning the activities of the Friedrich Weinreb (original title:”Rapport door het Rijksinstituut voor Oorlogsdocumentatie uitgebracht aan de Minister van Justitie inzake de activiteiten van drs. F. Weinreb), by D. Giltay Veth and A.J. van der Leeuw, 1976
data.description: In 1973, the RIOD issued a report on the collaboration of Friederich Weinreb, a man of Jewish origin who had been both hailed for his brave actions during the war to save Jews and accused of de facto collaboration, The quest for moral grounds concerning collaborationa and resistance was not however a historigraphical debate. It is telling that RIOD, an institution which had concentrated the documentation on “occupation” of the Netherlands, to centre stage in the  political dispute between the left and the right in Dutch politics at the time. The case brought against Weinreb shows both a deep reconsideration of memory politics across time, the way the image of the resistance was embroiled with contemporary politics and the specific change in the way witnesses and the Holocaust became gradually a matter of social widespread guilt and regret, rather than individual trajectories and suffering.  Indeed, when Friedrich Weinreb decided to publish his memoirs in 1969, Collaboratie en verzet 1940-1945, he did so with the close collaboration of Renate Rubinstein and Aad Nuis, two journalists on the left side of the political spectrum. The war and resistance were a heroic narrative equally resonant to those who asked for more radical expressions in Dutch politics as a whole. Rubinstein’s weekly columns in Vrij Nederland, which started to appear in 1962 were a pertinent social commentary, widely read at the time.  In 1969, the fact that an influential journalist on the left was willing to support of a member of the Jewish community who had been previously been accused of collaboration is of significance in itself. The 1960s were a time of intense contestations in Dutch politics, with massive street movements directed against the government (provos) and where state establishment was being heavily questioned. The role of resistance, opposition, leftism and Jewish resistance were crucial in these debates about the political spectrum. Like in Germany, the memory of the war was central to the political debate, as many were contesting the credentials and the credibility of key indivisuals in administration and political parties. Their actions during the war were being scrutinized less for an interest in the conflict, but more so to establish a form of “moral highground”. These actions and the debate were symptomatic for a changing memory politics around the Second World War which was growingly turning to the global Holocaust remembrace discourse. In a Dutch history dominated by heroic images of resistance, there were many episodes which became candidates to be integrated in this memory canon but there was an increasing sensitivity to the narratives set in place immediately after the war. There was an interest, one might argue, in a functional history, one that could mediate of sorts the political sphere. The publication changed and influenced a particular type of the image of the collaboration.  With passages such as N/A, the impression was one of a man who reacted to circumstances, rather than care for strong political statements. Almost none of the opponents of Weinreb, whether they were Germans or Jews, were actually endowed with any privilege that might have been of interest to him. Consequently, yhe image he constructed was rather that of a disobedient rebel, also prone to tricking a highly organized SS in the Netherlands, a rather "bourgeois disobedience of the rebel," of the man who stood alone in his struggle against the bureaucracy, which he often outwitted. Weireb’s selfstyled resistance and what is evidently a work of disculpation by placing blame on circumstances, government and others resonated with the deep fractures between left and right which were the main field of social and political debate in “Western” Europe in the 1960s.

page_blocks.text: First and foremost, it suggested to what extent “resistance” was a “usable” past after the war. It was a struggle of public and wide debate, shaped by historiography but reaching far into the public sphere. Immediately after the war, accounts circulated but were often coloured by the relief of the end of the war. The difficulties encountered in publishing the diary of Anne Frank in the first years after the war are illustrative of this. These changes also coincided with different voices, sometimes more critical on the war politics, which emerged in the 1960s and 1970s, in comparison to the prior decade, for instance, Etty Hillesum. The memory conflict and debate about resistance and opposition was shaped by the two foremost visible historians of the time, Leo de Jong and Jacques Presser, who had different opinions on the matter. In the 1960s, Loe de Jong dealt with the persecution of Jews in his television series The Occupation, a widely popular show and an important memory device of the age. Interestingly, a case like Weinreb, who had been prosecuted in 1948 for his contribution to the deportation but served virtually no time in prison due to the amnesty for Queen Wilhemina’s jubileum, was a far too controversial case to feature at all in the series. Jacques Presser, on the other hand, dedicated consistent passages to his character in the canonical book Ondergang: De vervolging en verdelging van het Nederlandse Jodendom 1940-1945 primarily because of the side of the type of history he portrayed, that of compromise, rather than opposition. He was a side of a deeply contested and debated length and seriousness of the Jewish resistance and complicity. Interestingly, as the image of the resistance was being shaped either by the underground non-Jewish resistance or soldiers in the Dutch army, there were far more visible “moral” doubts about Jewish institutions.

data.title: A diary
data.description: The diary of Etty Hillesum was only published in 1979, after numerous attempts by writer Klaas Smelik, whom she entrusted with the manuscript. Hillesum, of Jewish origin worked, initially for the Jewish Council in the camp and had an opportunity to escape. She decided, however, to stay next to her family in the camp and also document the regime inside, interactions and personal despair as the fate of those insides were becoming more apparent with time. Hillesum wrote evocative accounts from it to her friends, later published as in the early 1950s as “Letters from Westerbork”. Her diary, however, a depiction of the thought and political assessment of the Netherlands before the war of an unorthodox young woman of Jewish origin in Amsterdam was a more problematic text. Her musings over complicity, responsibility and ethics challenged the perception of the victim of the Holocaust. Like Philip Mechanicus, Hillesum is, in fact, one of the rare voices of witnesses who did not survive the Shoah but left behind a critical testimony of the context and the compromises which led to mass murder. The book poses interesting questions about the type of voice telling the story of camp, not as a survivor, but as a victim who never had the opportunity to reconsider opinions at the height of the social polarisation.

page_blocks.text: In 1946–1948, Dutch Jews established the only semipermanent honor court (Joodse Ereraad) in Western Europe, an organization which was meant to investigate the morality of actions of members of the community, otherwise widespread in Eastern Europe. It investigated and instrumentalized around twenty cases of abuse, among which the most visible and far reaching was that of the heads of the Joodse Raad during the war, David Cohen and Abraham Asscher, to whom a lackadaisical attitude concerning the position of the Amsterdam Raad with the occupying forces was imputed.

page_blocks.text: The attitude of the organization had been tolerant towards the deportations, actively working together with the occupiers to administer the camp, and in particular Westerbork, where it was present continously, helping internees with packages and other supplies and communication with the outside. But in 1943, both Asscher and Cohen were interned in the camp from where they were deported to Theresienstadt which they survived, but did not limit the suspicion concerning their actions during the war. The trial effectively terminated any official functions they might hold in the Jewish community. In 1956, the memoires of David Cohen, leader of the Jewish Council brought to the fore controversial questions about the organization. Weinreb was a similar disputed case, and was tried in 1948 but freed after 6 months. His case, in particular, contributed in a deeply divisive debate about the Jewish “resistance” which started with the case around the directors of the Jewish Council early after the war. Pardoned, however, his story in fact provided an alternative narrative to the other trials. It equally emerged in a context focused almost exclusively on an affirmative memory. Indeed, the context of collaborators was more complicated after the war. Notes from survivors of Westerbork for instance suggests a reluctance of the authorities in engaging with mass-scale actions against collaborators. Many of these were evident among survivors of Westerbork, like Werner Sterzenbach, who were trying to make sense of the responsibility and responses post-war.

page_blocks.text:
Much of the debates at the time issues focused on how exactly one can describe resistance. There were individuals actions that many took, from helping people in hiding, distributing illegal newspapers or blowing up railway lines. So were the propaganda leaflets which insisted on larger actions. Publishing manifestos and newspapers for awareness was the activity which made resistance neworks come together .The type of resistance that prevailed differed per phase of the occupation and was closely re lated to the German measures and the course of the war. There was a sporadic mobilization of former members of the military but their influence was limited. The communist resistance was less developed as in neighbouring countries, primarily due to a rather weak presence on the political local spectrum.

In 1940, the small Communist party went into hiding, where Paul de Groot, the leader, initiated the publication of de Waarheid (the Truth). By 1941, there was a strong network of support which initiated the Februaristaking (walks out in Amsterdam and Zaandam) of workers protesting against the treatment of the Jewish community. Landelijke Organisatie (LO) was set up with the direct purpose of hiding those to be deported. For the fake papers, documents there was a continous “annoyance” of German authorities but the actions were considered to be kept under control by the SS. Binnenlandse Strijdkrachten , the local traces of the army decided often against guerilla actions. It was in this contrast that the memory of the resistance emerged after the war as a crucial binding force. Its character was predominanly military and . Westerbork is a good example of this, as the first monument on site was a esistance monument opened at Westerbork on 4th of May 1949 a r, next to the crematory, the place were all of the resistance fighters and escaped prisoners were shot. This monument officially commemorated only those shot elswhere in 1943 in Drenthe brought to Westerbork and cremated there. A small number of resistance fighters were shot at Westerbork and 4 escaped prisoners were shot (one still alive was put to death by a doctor afterwards).

page_blocks.text:
Some of the claims that emerged in that debate had clear legal implications. It was the case of Bep Turksma, a young Jewish woman who managed to escape from Westerbork in 1942, who had been on one of the lists of Weinreb and who he argued had reported him to the SD, presumably affecting the chances of his plans. Turksma initiated a legal case against the publication of Collaboration and Resistance and filed two criminal complaints against Weinreb, Rubinstein for defamation. Although the RIOD report would establish a decade later that her claims were true, the judge at the time decided that she could not prove her claims. The verdict occassioned further campaigning in Vrij Nederland against Turksma.

Interestingly, the passages about her were erased in the edition of 1971 of his bioraphy. It is significant in this sense that a case started in 1969, was weakened by 1979. This story of inside the Weinreb affaire suggests a remarkable shift in just one decade concerning the survivors of the war and of Westerbork itself. From their silencing in face of a canonical memory which seemed to insist on the heroic memory of those who tried to do something, an almost utilitarian view on the resistance, to the 1971 moment, when the National Monument for the Holocaust, designed by Ralf Prins had been just installed on the site.

page_blocks.text: In fact, although the debate itself questioned the grounds of many memorial images and history perspectives, it is telling that as the debate about the publication came to question the guilt possibly attributed to Weinreb, there were many more voices not often questioned the verdict in the trial of Weinreb, which had been one of the most followed at the time. Fred Polak asked Minister of Justice Ivo Samkalden on 25 May 1965 whether this was not seen in Presser's study as a reason to revise the judgment. Samkalden answered in the negative: Presser might have a different opinion on the criminal case against Weinreb, but he had not provided any new information. A few legal scholars shared Samkalden's sobering judgment: Presser's argument was emotional and made no sense legally; Weinreb was correctly sentenced in 1948. The historian M.C. Brands, a student and employee of Presser, wrote in the Volkskrant of 23 May 1969: 'What is missing or forgotten in this work is difficult to determine. According to a connoisseur like Presser, this is little. I therefore cannot imagine that this valuable document does not give our Minister of Justice any reason to take steps. It is high time.

Only 5,000 deportees survived the war. After Poland, the Germans were nowhere more successful in the extermination of Jews than in the Netherlands.  Yet the camp was controlled by only a few German SS officers, with help of some SS trained volunteers from German and Amsterdam police battalions and the Dutch Waffen SS, housed in the nearby SS camp Hooghalen, or Heidelager. The Dutch military police (Marechaussee) continued to guard the camp inside, assisted by a Jewish camp police. The latter, the OD (Ordnungsdienst), distinctive in their green overalls (since 1943) who had to help with the transports, garnered the worst reputation among Dutch Jewish inmates as the ‘Jewish SS’.  Westerbork underwent a new transformation after the liberation, when between 1945 and 1948 it came to serve as an internment camp for members of the Dutch National Socialist Party (NSB), SS volunteers and other people suspected of having collaborated with the Nazis. It also briefly served as a training base for soldiers during the Indonesian War of Independence  (1945-1949) and a camp for Dutch repatriates from the Dutch Indies. From 1951 to 1970 the camp, renamed Schattenberg, became the residence of a large part of former Moluccan soldiers of the Royal Netherlands East Indies Army  (KNIL) with their families, who left the island of Ambon after the Indonesian repression of their independence movement. Two decades after living in the camp, the Moluccans saw their camp demolished after the government approved the project of the Westerbork Synthesis Radio Telescope on the campscape. The Schattenberg community was relocated to surrounding villages. With the exception of the camp commander’s house and the 1949 Resistance Monument, the campscape was already half empty when in 1970 the National Monument Camp Westerbork was unveiled, and in 1983, three kilometres away from the silence zone, the Memorial Centre  Camp Westerbork was opened. From then on Jewish survivors held regular commemorations and the annual number of visitors rose constantly, reaching 180,000 in 2019. Since 2000 the Memorial Center has made room for research and presentations on the wider biography of the site, but confronted itself in 2008 with strong protests against its temporary exhibition of the NSB period, after which the museum and the “holy ground” of the campscape have become separated spaces, the latter mainly dedicated to Holocaust commemoration. Yet, within the current context of a growing competition of Holocaust and postcolonial memories, and the refugee issue, the memorialization of the various groups which went through Westerbork and Schattenberg, and their divergent experiences including the role of the perpetrators, remains contested up to today.

title: Divided memories and rights in Westerbork

page_blocks.text: In Germany, during the commemoration of Kristallnacht in November 2008, 70 years after the 9-13 November Pogrom, tensions about the meaning of memory emerged.  Instead of a united protest against the rise of right-wing anti-Semitism, the established CDU-CSU, SPD, FDP and the Green Party refused to sign a common declaration with the radical-left party Die Linke because of its past critiques of Israel during the Gaza War (2008-2009). This divided commemoration triggered the anger of the Secretary of the German Jewish Central Council Stephan Kramer, who warned against the political use, misuse and divisions in which the Holocaust was just a pawn. The real danger of a rise of anti-Semitism was not located in Palestine but in Germany itself, in the growing exclusion of its Turkish minority whose ‘foreign’ mosques were treated almost the same as the 1400 Jewish synagogues destroyed in the November Pogrom once, and which could make them prey for Muslim extremism. (iv)   The equation between the Holocaust and debates about contemporary rights entangle visibly on sites of heritage, like Westerbork, which have been used repeatedly and continue to stand as memorial debate. Here, yearly commemorations, separated between the veterans, the Jewish community and the Moluccan community,  bring in debates about who holds rights as veterans, of citizenship. With the centrality of the Holocaust however in memory debates, the history of granting and losing rights and the way these contributed to the general tragedy of the war, what conditioned for survivors still who was “ours” and who was not, made way for the equalizing identity of Holocaust victims.

page_blocks.text: The heritage of camps has been synonimous with the ebbs and flows of rights but also a memory of disenfranchisement.  Westerbork itself was built in light of the dramatic change in Europe in 1938 (14) in the conception of rights, and the “stateless” dimension of the space is perhaps best explained by the fact that the “central refugee camp” was constructed due to the financial support of the Dutch and international Jewish community by Jewish refugees themselves (16). It was a time of consistent debates about rights, for instance, labour rights. At the time, for instance, the  Dutch government attempted to activate workers who because of the economic depression had lost their jobs. The job creation policy program led to a system of labour camps for Dutch unemployed (17) and in particular for illegal refugees who were no longer allowed to work in regular jobs. They were offered agricultural jobs in a parallel system of fenced refugee camps such as Heijplaat in Rotterdam (19). This parallel system of work, which equally placed refugees in conditions of disenfranchisement, with small groups of German Jewish refugees working in a number of Zionist kibbutzim and hakhshara (agricultural) training centres as to prepare themselves for emigration to Palestine. When the war broke out, Zionist pioneer camps like the Deventer Association (1918) and, in particular, the modern agricultural school complex Werkdorp Wieringermeer (1934) each had some three hundred workers registered.(xxxxx) There was a clear connection between such unemployment camps, the rightless status of those inside and the turn of the war. From Wieringermeer, for instance, under its last Jewish director, the lawyer Abel Herzberg, everyone was evacuated in 1941 by the Amsterdam Sicherheitsdienst. Most refugees were sent to the new Amsterdam ghetto, from where with the second razzia (raid) on 11 June the majority of these Werkdorp Jews were deported first to Camp Schoorl, a punishment camp for political opponents like the communist leaders of the Amsterdam February Strike of 1941. Just like the Jewish victims of the first Amsterdam raid of 22-23 February (which would lead to the February Strike)(20), they would however from there almost immediately be deported to Mauthausen (Austria), where most of them died within a few months after arrival.

data.description: Accompanied by Amsterdam police, two public busses from the Amsterdam network carried illegal Jewish immigrants back to Germany. Besides this report, the social-democratic newspaper Zaans Volksblad publishes a critical letter to the editor asking “Are these refugees’ lives in danger?”

page_blocks.text: From the beginning of the German occupation, Dutch Jews were treated on paper already as potential refugees. Indeed, for its first occupants, Westerbork brought a temporary respite in an otherwise precarious existence. Anti-refugee sentiments were often stirred up on a local level by right-wing neighbours who did not like the idea of having foreigners in their countryside. An NSB  farm leader in Wieringermeer hated them because of their possession of land meant for “Dutch” farmers (xx). After the beginning of the deportations in February 1941, when there was a little distinction being made anymore between Jewish residents and “stateless” German-Jewish refugees. Jews were needed, on the one hand, for forced labour in the war industry,  whereas on the other, war introduced more easy and violent ways to exclude the millions of Polish and Russian Jews in the newly occupied Eastern territories. It was to these regions that from mid 1942 also many Westerbork Jews were deported. Both groups were from then on treated in the same way as internees of the same transit camp waiting to be deported to the eastern labour-, concentration or extermination camps, sometimes the one treated more brutal, or offered more privileges than the other.   The issue of rights and the way these are weaved in the history and memory of Westerbork is multifarious.

page_blocks.text:
The discriminatory bureaucratic practices were not only the apanage of Nazi Germany. In the late 1930s,  the initial discriminatory registrations of Jewish refugees which would pave the way for the later Nazi deportation and extermination of the Jews were the concern of many other, “liberal” regimes.  Against Germany’s wish for open borders to let the Jews go, some neighbouring countries were making use of the Nazi government to reinforce border control. Switzerland, with the support of Sweden, asked the German government for “J” stamps in the travel papers of Jewish refugees which would allow Jews to be recognized as ‘illegals” at the borders and immediately deported to refugee camps  (xv). On October 5, 1938, the Reich Ministry of the Interior invalidates all German passports held by Jews. Jews must surrender their old passports, which will become valid only after the letter “J” has been stamped on them. The government required Jews to identify themselves in ways that would permanently separate them from the rest of the German population. In an August 1938 law, authorities decreed that by January 1, 1939, Jewish men and women bearing first names of “non-Jewish” origin had to add “Israel” and “Sara,” respectively, to their given names. All German Jews were obliged to carry identity cards that indicated their heritage, and, in the autumn of 1938, all Jewish passports were stamped with an identifying red letter “J”. But the “J-passport” was not a German invention as often thought and it was soon used in Nazi propaganda as proof that Jews were unwelcomed everywhere.  The J-passport also effectively ended the possibility of free travel which in Europe had existed up to the First World War, at least under the precondition that migrants could provide for their own maintenance. And even though the Nazis were not responsible for the highly effective registration of Jewish refugees, it offered them an instrument soon to be used on normal Jewish populations. (xvxv).

Jews were asked to register as such everywhere. In the Netherlands, their voluntary registration in fact provided also a comprehensive instrument for the Nazi occupying authorities to register and to qualify the numbers and the locations of the Jewish community in Europe.

data.title: Testimony of a priviledged inmate
data.description: Kurt Schlesinger was one of the initial German refugees interned in the camp, and came to supervise the transports. He was a witness in Gemmeker's trial but his own contribution to the deportations was rarely discussed. He emigrated, after several years to the United States, where he passed away in 1963. His testimony emphasizes the circumstances of his actions

page_blocks.text: The “illegal” refugees were therefore in a different situation than the Jewish Dutch and the distinctions showed even in the mechanisms of defence against the authorities of occupation. Refugees, often supported and informed by transnational networks, were more informed of the fate of the community under the Nazi regime. This difference of situation triggered it itself demarcations which endured. In the transit camp Westerbork, the “Germans” (the first refugees who were concentrated after the building of the refugee camp) held the main service positions from the immediate opening in 1939 to almost the final period of the camp (20). Testimonies of German refugees speak about the growing rivalries with the “Dutch” after their arrival since July 1942. Dutch Jews associated the former refugees, now changed into higher ranged “camp eldest”, because of their common language, their often ‘collaborating’ role as members of the OD (Order Police, internal to the camp), and their possession of the best, family barracks, often with the German perpetrators (21). Both groups, however, were caught in a rivalry which had more to do with the history and microcosm of the camp than with their supposed national habits. (22) Their post-war lives, and the fact that relatively many of the camp elite survived the war, emigrated and rebuilt their lives, fueled this memory conflict until decades after the war (21).

data.title: Hans Margules’ alien’s passport, 1940
data.description: This official document for an alien (“vreemdeling”) delivered by the local council of Westerbork has a portrait of Hans Margules from 1940. The passport was stamped with “J” for “Jew” by the German occupiers in 1942, and stamped again after the liberation in 1945 by the local aliens’ police in Amsterdam.

data.title: Westerbork
data.description: The Westerbork camp in the Netherlands testifies to overlapping histories of politics of exclusion and inclusion. It was established in 1939, after the Dutch borders were closed down for refugees by the government, as a central refugee camp for Jews who fled from Germany and Anschluss Austria. In total, after Hitler’s ascent to power in 1933, almost 32,000 German Jews found refuge in the Netherlands, some 10,000 after the 1938 November or Kristallnacht pogroms. At the beginning of the German occupation in May 1940 it hosted only 750 refugees, but when the Nazis turned the refugee camp into a transit camp in July 1942 the camp was enlarged with new barracks for Dutch Jews. Already since February 1941 Dutch and German Jews were caught by Nazi raids (razzia’s) in the Amsterdam Judenviertel and in other cities, but from July 1942 until the beginning of the railway strike of September 1944 the Polizeiliches Judendurchgangslager Westerbork served that function. In close cooperation with the Amsterdam Jewish Council (Joodse Raad) at about 107,000 (of a total of 145,000 Dutch Jews), and 245 Sinti and Roma, of 97 transports were selected for weekly deportations to concentration and extermination camps in Germany and Eastern Europe, most of them to Auschwitz-Birkenau and Sobibor. The façade of a seemingly peaceful place where people waited in fear on the deadly transports was described in painful details by the Dutch journalist Philip Mechanicus in his camp diary In Depot and in the letters and diaries of Etty Hillesum, and filmed by the German-Jewish photographer Rudolf Breslauer for his 1944 Westerbork film, of which the footage (since 2017 registered as UNESCO Memory of the World) contains the only known real-life moving images of a Nazi train transport. Only 5,000 deportees survived the war. After Poland, the Germans were nowhere more successful in the extermination of Jews than in the Netherlands.  Yet the camp was controlled by only a few German SS officers, with help of some SS trained volunteers from German and Amsterdam police battalions and the Dutch Waffen SS, housed in the nearby SS camp Hooghalen, or Heidelager. The Dutch military police (Marechaussee) continued to guard the camp inside, assisted by a Jewish camp police. The latter, the OD (Ordnungsdienst), distinctive in their green overalls (since 1943) who had to help with the transports, garnered the worst reputation among Dutch Jewish inmates as the ‘Jewish SS’.  Westerbork underwent a new transformation after the liberation, when between 1945 and 1948 it came to serve as an internment camp for members of the Dutch National Socialist Party (NSB), SS volunteers and other people suspected of having collaborated with the Nazis. It also briefly served as a training base for soldiers during the Indonesian War of Independence  (1945-1949) and a camp for Dutch repatriates from the Dutch Indies. From 1951 to 1970 the camp, renamed Schattenberg, became the residence of a large part of former Moluccan soldiers of the Royal Netherlands East Indies Army  (KNIL) with their families, who left the island of Ambon after the Indonesian repression of their independence movement. Two decades after living in the camp, the Moluccans saw their camp demolished after the government approved the project of the Westerbork Synthesis Radio Telescope on the campscape. The Schattenberg community was relocated to surrounding villages. With the exception of the camp commander’s house and the 1949 Resistance Monument, the campscape was already half empty when in 1970 the National Monument Camp Westerbork was unveiled, and in 1983, three kilometres away from the silence zone, the Memorial Centre  Camp Westerbork was opened. From then on Jewish survivors held regular commemorations and the annual number of visitors rose constantly, reaching 180,000 in 2019. Since 2000 the Memorial Center has made room for research and presentations on the wider biography of the site, but confronted itself in 2008 with strong protests against its temporary exhibition of the NSB period, after which the museum and the “holy ground” of the campscape have become separated spaces, the latter mainly dedicated to Holocaust commemoration. Yet, within the current context of a growing competition of Holocaust and postcolonial memories, and the refugee issue, the memorialization of the various groups which went through Westerbork and Schattenberg, and their divergent experiences including the role of the perpetrators, remains contested up to today.

page_blocks.text: In 2017, Sieg Maandag, a survivor from Bergen Belsen, passed away. He reminded public opinion not of an individual story of survival, but of the uncomfortable and harrowing presence that images of war have been ever since. In April 1945, he fell under the photographic gaze of British photojournalist George Rodger, who was, as most at the time, looking to convey what seemed to be all of a sudden the hidden tragedies of the Nazi camp system. Maandag, an eight-year-old boy, was, in that famous picture, looking rather confused in the opposite direction of a road lined with corpses. For a long time, Maandag was almost synonymous to an image of innocence lost, of many generations having to deal and live with the reality of the war as the documentary evidence, those who had survived and were telling their stories and demanding people not to turn a blind eye were increasing. Roger’s very career testified to these issues: he set up Magnum, together with Robert Capa, another man shaped by war, and yet he refused to work in conflict zones, conflicted about the ethics of this documentation. Paradoxically, two years after Maandag’s death, in 2019, when the same picture was used in an exhibition in Amsterdam, it became evident that Maandag’s picture in Life magazine in 1945 had been indeed difficult for the American and worldwide public. The dead, arguably those who died because of the deadly typhus epidemics during the last days of the camp and in the first weeks after liberation, had been airbrushed. The debate focused on this selective truth of war which has been reproduced in the last seven decades, but it equally says something about the way images of war are used, disused and selectively become the symbol of conflict.

data.title: "People should see the original photo of Sieg Maandag"

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: Documenting camps

page_blocks.text:
In the very least, the fact that a form of documentation, albeit the only such glimpse into a daily life of the camp, is turned into an object of heritage is an interesting issue. In 2017, the Westerbork movie, the only material filmed in the concentration camps, became UNESCO world heritage. It a sense, this change not only speaks about the awareness given to camps and to war in the age of “regret” but also that traces and representations of camps become, as Timothy Mitchell argues, images that do, and that they mobilize an understanding of history, a new way of finding direct relevance in this. Knowledge over the camps has been a dynamic process, over decades. The relevance of diaries and journals of prisoners or survivors has varied with the depth and the urgency of the remembrance of the war. Etty Hillesum, a critical Jewish voice on the political conditions and compromises which led to the persecutions of the Jewish community, wrote a diary in the camp which survived her. She perished in Auschwitz in 1943, and although her writings were well known for insiders, her diary reached public prominence only in the 1970s. Arguably, its renewed visibility depended on the growing place of the Holocaust in international debates of the 1970s in Western Europe and the United States. Although constantly revisited, for instance during the turning point of "1968", the opposition to the Vietnam War and debates about the Six Days War (1967), the issue of past atrocities reached a more coherent form towards the end of that decade. A different, but equally important shift occurred in the socialist bloc, where Jewish members of the Communist parties were purged, together with the reorientation away from the "anti-fascist" reading of the Second World War. 

The image of the camps was instrumental in the creation of the post-war humanitarian institutional framework as much as it defined the condition of the refugees in the context of the Cold War and the post-colonial dimension of international politics. The DP (displaced person) camps were a fixture of Europe post-war, with millions of people deciding or being forced to live in their former detention spaces because of uncertainties elsewhere. Many former inmates from Eastern Europe decided to stay behind in order to avoid the new socialist regimes in their countries of origins. As much as their presence was often a complex situation for British or Western governments who were the architects of the post-war humanitarian effort, the DP camps and their inhabitants also represented a powerful anti-Soviet image. Returning individuals to their home countries became a high stake and a divisive issue but went hand in hand with the visibility of the former camps post-war. With frequent protests of those in camps, for either support for relocation, or as in the case of Bergen Belsen, for arguing a political cause of a state, in this case Israel, the image of the camps, and their relevance for a type of public consciousness of solidarity is traceable in protests, public appeals of survivors, particularly children.

data.title: The Westerbork movie
data.description: In the spring of 1944, Jewish deportee Rudolf Breslauer documented the everyday life in the Westerbork transit camp on film. The film was commissioned by the commander of the camp, Albert Gemmeker, who meant, most probably, to produce a professional record of the economic value of the facility. Breslauer documented the Tuesday train transports to other concentration camps, though most images picture ‘moments of normalcy’; healthy men and women working in workshops, playing sports, children at school, or scenes at the hospital, cabaret and even a church service. Next to stills showing the orderly camp, the productive daily labour and even football matches in the camp, the film follows trains and transports, the horror of anonymous faces, of all ages, some starving, some still unknowing as the trains depart. Breslauer never got to finalise the Westerbork film, but much of the raw footage is preserved, in different versions. Since 1948, fragments of the film are widely used in documentaries, films and newsreels and as evidence in the postwar trial against Gemmeker. Footage of the transports, especially the scene of the Dutch Sinti girl Settela Steinbach who looks at the lens behind the doors of a boxcar, became iconic for the systematic anonymization of the victims of the Nazis. The film remains the only filmed documentation of a concentration camp during the war. It was listed under UNESCO heritage in 2018, as a unique instance of heritage of perpetratorship.

files.type_os: ISO Media, MPEG v4 system, version 1

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: Documenting camps

file.type_os: ISO Media, MPEG v4 system, version 1

page_blocks.text:
Indeed, as heritage, the imagery of war and conflict have been central less to the remembrance of war and more so the precaution against war, a discourse of prevention which places imagery of war at the intersection of a didactic, social meaning of war. It was in fact, something happening not only in the documentary interest of people like Rodger. The Allied photography during the war was a strong presence in press and footage and newsreel on the exploits on the front, from newsreel to news. The mobilization of this type of images during the war was to present the war as a heroic exploit against the Nazis but also a motivation of the extensive mobilization of effort. The Soviet press at the time was equally covering the extensive “antifascist” campaign, as perhaps best illustrates the famous “Raising a Flag over the Reichstag” by Yevgeny Khaldei (3). The heroism of war was synonymous, in this context, with the documentation and the unravelling of the power to deceive of the defeated enemies. 

 Investigations and dramatic mock trials exposed and denounced some injustices, but short-circuited in the face of others. The insistence of many campaigns on the repeatability of the Nazi camp system was both a source of its power to judge and a weakness. When confronted with situations in which past and present could not be compared so easily, the efforts fell short and often meant campaigns refused “racial” victims and did not engage the issue of genocide.

page_blocks.text: Whether that was indeed the situation during the war is a more nuanced question. The camps, in particular, were meant to be hidden, the very notion of camp implies an isolation and disenfranchisement of the individual, but they were, by no means, really invisible. Reports from the camp circulated through Europe all through the 5 years. The Polish Jan Karksi spoke about the inferno in occupied Poland as soon as 1940 as a matter of international affairs with the British, French and Soviet governments. The Vrba Wetzler report with testimonies smuggled out of Auschwitz kept headlines in 1943 all through Europe. The suffering of the Jews in camps was known.

data.title: The mass extermination of Jews in German-occupied Poland
data.description: A report addressed by Jan Karski to the UN in 1942

data.title: Vrba Wetzler Report from Auschwitz in 1944

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: Documenting camps

page_blocks.text:
But Allied phototography was equally important to the situation post-war. The “forced confrontations” imposed by the Allies to members of the communities around dictated, of sorts, the image and the use of images of atrocity, of death and the violent deaths suffered in the war. Images of these moments were perhaps as powerful as the images of bodies themselves. The "victory" against a barbaric regime was instrumental, for instance, in the political negotiations between Great Britain and the United States with Stalin's USSR. Championing the cause of human dignity in the victory of the war represented also a leverage against the internal repressive politics of USSR at that time. 

The camera roll intensified, in fact, towards the end of the war, in providing witness accounts and documenting acts of witness, particularly with the release of photographs documenting the Holocaust. Popular magazines, such as Life, brought graphic images to the American and British publics. Alongside Roger, there were Margaret Bourke-White, Willaim Vandevert whose photo essays, entitled Atrocities, were similar with the coverage years later of the Spanish Civil War. " Dead men will have indeed died in vain if live men refuse to look at them", argued Bourke-White. In fact, responding to the revelations in the camp, general Eisenhower demanded a "mass witnessing".

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: Documenting camps

page_blocks.text:
But the case of Roger’s retouching suggests however that images of atrocity have been difficult to debate even as the war was going on or ending. This debate, about the ethics of responsibility, whether this owes primarily to the dignity of the victim, or on the contrary, to the ethics of social knowledge about war and conflict in general continues today. Theorist Barbie Zelizer argues this type of representation is even in danger of representing these atrocities in a stereotypical manner which fundamentally come to erase their history and the genealogy, and consequently the conditions which might maintain their reference today. At the same time, despite the wealth of information on the violence being associated to the US and the United Kingdom, in particular, Western media was for instance cautious to report the violence, primarily because such information often emerged out of Soviet sources. The fact that the Soviet Army liberated concentrations camps affected the public responses and visibility of the phenomenon. Foreign correspondents were for instance invited to Majdanek, in Poland, for documentation, and they reacted partly with uncertainty about the source. Yet, Majdanek, or rather documentation of camps became a standard of bearing witness. It showed however the different perspectives on the matter: Soviet photography showed the ruin and destruction, gas chambers and crematoria without focusing on the victims. By the end of 1944, when American troops also began partaking in these acts of "educational" public witnessing, the focus moved towards the physical demise of victims.

The representation of camps was an important dimension of the Cold War. The International Commission Against the Concentration Camp Regime (CICRC) established in 1949 by the French intellectual and Nazi camp survivor David Rousset, in the wake of the Second World War, for instance, called upon fellow deportees who had been detained for their political activities to serve as expert witnesses to Nazism’s “concentrationary universe” and to oppose any repetition of its crimes in the postwar world.

The extent to which such images were to the displayed is a constant question for memorials and museums, for instance: does too much exposure desensitize the viewer? Does the viewer engage in a voyeuristic gesture, inevitably, when in contact with such images and hence diminish both their effect and undercut the very purpose of their purpose for the victim?

data.title: A diary
data.description: The diary of Etty Hillesum was only published in 1979, after numerous attempts by writer Klaas Smelik, whom she entrusted with the manuscript. Hillesum, of Jewish origin worked, initially for the Jewish Council in the camp and had an opportunity to escape. She decided, however, to stay next to her family in the camp and also document the regime inside, interactions and personal despair as the fate of those insides were becoming more apparent with time. Hillesum wrote evocative accounts from it to her friends, later published as in the early 1950s as “Letters from Westerbork”. Her diary, however, a depiction of the thought and political assessment of the Netherlands before the war of an unorthodox young woman of Jewish origin in Amsterdam was a more problematic text. Her musings over complicity, responsibility and ethics challenged the perception of the victim of the Holocaust. Like Philip Mechanicus, Hillesum is, in fact, one of the rare voices of witnesses who did not survive the Shoah but left behind a critical testimony of the context and the compromises which led to mass murder. The book poses interesting questions about the type of voice telling the story of camp, not as a survivor, but as a victim who never had the opportunity to reconsider opinions at the height of the social polarisation.

title: The ambivalent memory of state involvement in Westerbork

page_blocks.text: In 2016, the NS (Nederlandse Spoorwegen), the Dutch Railway company agreed to pay several tens of millions of euros as compensations for the transports the company facilitated during the deportations from the Dutch concentration camps to the East. The attempt applies to members of the Jewish and the Roma community exclusively. In 2005, the company had already apologized for its actions during the war, consequently, in 2016, historian Job Cohen, who was in charge of the report leading up to the financial compensations was musing “ How could this have only happened so recently?” (1) in reference to the delay in the offering the compensation (2). The initiator of the project, Salo Muller, whose family was deported to Auschwitz, made the point that a financial compensation will actually “inflict” pain and cause a wound to the organization, which will not be absolved with only an apology.  At the same time, public opinion also noticed perhaps the need to broaden the compensation categories, to people who were persecuted as resistance fighters, as communists, therefore not exclusively on racial grounds.

page_blocks.text: The debate is illustrative of how difficult it has been to negotiate a “memory” of state institutions as perpetrators (1). It has represented an intersection of processes of making the history public and accountability concerning the past from the institutions involved.  Compensations, for instance, have become more widespread in international politics and in memory dynamics because it is an attitude which longer stops at abstract apologies, but is about reparations and direct action for survivors or families of survivors. As Stiina Loytomaki argues “ criminal convictions end up individualizing guilt and responsibility whereas paying reparations is a way of assuming some notion of collective responsibility. It is a way of holding perpetrators to moral standard and equally, a manner of showing another angle to the trespassing of the perpetrator has been resolved and accounted for.  In fact, apologies do not necessarily entail a more neutral and objective look at history. These have generated equal public posturing. Recently, the head of the PVV Geert Wilders was criticizing the “shameful” actions of Queen Wilhemina during the occupation about the same time that prime minister Mark Rutte publicly apologized for the Holocaust.(I) The debate still suggests that the “memory of perpetrators” is difficult to just integrate into an idea “state normalization after a conflict, in particular when these collaborators were state organizations(3).

page_blocks.text: The issue of actions of state institutions and the way this legacy has been incorporated in the post-war period has often been either silenced or uncomfortable to look at. The actions during the war of institutions which are central to the state: police, military, state bureaucracy more generally has been the question of debate. (i) Indeed, the debate has transferred to an issue of trust, of “social contract”, between citizen and state, which needs to be respected, and obeyed.  Guilt and narrowly defined shame have been constructions associated with notions of identity. Much of the efforts of post-war reconstruction, for instance, have been centred on the idea of the rebuilding trust between such institutions and the citizens at the end of war. Much of the debates but also silences around the topic emerged out of the discussions about these histories.

data.title: Margules on guilt, 2012
data.description: In 2012 Hans Margules wrote this letter to Frank van Riet, policeman and author, in response to his letter about the OD: “100,000 people went through camp Westerbork. Each of them experienced the camp in a different way. Who is guilty of our fate? The inmates of the camp? Or was it Nazi Germany, maybe? It is 65 years since the war is over, and in Holland, they are still searching for the culprit amidst us refugees? Well, keep on searching!”

page_blocks.text:
The involvement of authorities in the Jewish persecutions, for instance, has been a topic of debate. Such for instance were the police forces, which had an active role under the occupation and under the German SD regime. The role of the police in the Holocaust, particularly in the organized murder of Jews and Roma was instrumentalized by the Nazi state and their allies by involving the police at every stage of the genocidal process, from the arrest and looting of the victims to their deportation and killing. During Nazi occupation, non-German police units—some already in existence, some newly created—performed a range of key functions in pursuit of German goals, but also based on their own interests. How and why the police—as an executive agency of the state as well as an organized group of decision-making individuals—took part in the genocidal process across Europe, and examine the extent of their participation in different countries and contexts

 It was part of the reasons why the police forces were a disputed element in the society post-war, to the extent that documents suggest a low level of social conflict between citizens and police forces. The 1960s proved to be an instrumental decade in this mindset, and clashes at the time between police and citizens, especially in the second half of the 1960s sparked renewed debates about the handling and the participation of police forces during the Second World War. (9)

page_blocks.text:
As much as it has been appropriated, this idea of passive collaboration, or at least what we might term as the passive attitude of Dutch civil servants during the Holocaust has been treated differently as sensitivities post-war changed. 

In 1997, in France, the Gendermerie officially apologized for its actions during the deportations. In response, several journalists argued it might be time for the Dutch  NPB (Nederlandse Politiebond) to take the same position. In the official response, the organization argued ample “cleansing” of the institution had already taken place in the immediate aftermath of the war and did not require more attention. The situation was therefore not similar to that of France.

page_blocks.text: It did however recognize the existence of elements within the police that worked together with the “occupier”. There was little opposition to this affirmation, the few critics did not however notice a “blemish” which does not go away. Yet,  the role of the police, SD A letter of 1941 kept in the Westerbork archive begings by recalling how its author ended up in the Westerbork transit camp from Amsterdam: “early in the morning  two “rechercheurs” knocked on my door and indicated I should head to Centraal Station for Drenthe”(4) The organization insisted it has already been two-generation since the events.In 2015, in a recent article over their latest book, In de Frontlinie. Tien politiemannen en de Duitse bezetting, authors Guus Meershoek and Tommy van Es take concern with an older publication and argue “Aad van Liempt does not give a nuanced image of the police during the war”. (5) They refer here to van Liempt’s Jodenjacht. De onthutsende rol van de Nederlandse politie in de Tweede Wereldoorlog, which was one of the first in-depth study on the role of the Dutch Police in the deportations during the war. They continue: "We do not dispute that terrible things have happened, but since the 1980s a lot of research has been published on the police during the war. With that historical material it is possible to paint a nuanced picture. Van Liempt did not do that. We want to show with the stories of ten police officers that officers played different roles”. This recent debate suggests the ongoing debates when it comes to the memory of the involvement of state institutions in the repression during the war, especially when these are forces of control and order. (8)

data.title: Westerbork
data.description: The Westerbork camp in the Netherlands testifies to overlapping histories of politics of exclusion and inclusion. It was established in 1939, after the Dutch borders were closed down for refugees by the government, as a central refugee camp for Jews who fled from Germany and Anschluss Austria. In total, after Hitler’s ascent to power in 1933, almost 32,000 German Jews found refuge in the Netherlands, some 10,000 after the 1938 November or Kristallnacht pogroms. At the beginning of the German occupation in May 1940 it hosted only 750 refugees, but when the Nazis turned the refugee camp into a transit camp in July 1942 the camp was enlarged with new barracks for Dutch Jews. Already since February 1941 Dutch and German Jews were caught by Nazi raids (razzia’s) in the Amsterdam Judenviertel and in other cities, but from July 1942 until the beginning of the railway strike of September 1944 the Polizeiliches Judendurchgangslager Westerbork served that function. In close cooperation with the Amsterdam Jewish Council (Joodse Raad) at about 107,000 (of a total of 145,000 Dutch Jews), and 245 Sinti and Roma, of 97 transports were selected for weekly deportations to concentration and extermination camps in Germany and Eastern Europe, most of them to Auschwitz-Birkenau and Sobibor. The façade of a seemingly peaceful place where people waited in fear on the deadly transports was described in painful details by the Dutch journalist Philip Mechanicus in his camp diary In Depot and in the letters and diaries of Etty Hillesum, and filmed by the German-Jewish photographer Rudolf Breslauer for his 1944 Westerbork film, of which the footage (since 2017 registered as UNESCO Memory of the World) contains the only known real-life moving images of a Nazi train transport. Only 5,000 deportees survived the war. After Poland, the Germans were nowhere more successful in the extermination of Jews than in the Netherlands.  Yet the camp was controlled by only a few German SS officers, with help of some SS trained volunteers from German and Amsterdam police battalions and the Dutch Waffen SS, housed in the nearby SS camp Hooghalen, or Heidelager. The Dutch military police (Marechaussee) continued to guard the camp inside, assisted by a Jewish camp police. The latter, the OD (Ordnungsdienst), distinctive in their green overalls (since 1943) who had to help with the transports, garnered the worst reputation among Dutch Jewish inmates as the ‘Jewish SS’.  Westerbork underwent a new transformation after the liberation, when between 1945 and 1948 it came to serve as an internment camp for members of the Dutch National Socialist Party (NSB), SS volunteers and other people suspected of having collaborated with the Nazis. It also briefly served as a training base for soldiers during the Indonesian War of Independence  (1945-1949) and a camp for Dutch repatriates from the Dutch Indies. From 1951 to 1970 the camp, renamed Schattenberg, became the residence of a large part of former Moluccan soldiers of the Royal Netherlands East Indies Army  (KNIL) with their families, who left the island of Ambon after the Indonesian repression of their independence movement. Two decades after living in the camp, the Moluccans saw their camp demolished after the government approved the project of the Westerbork Synthesis Radio Telescope on the campscape. The Schattenberg community was relocated to surrounding villages. With the exception of the camp commander’s house and the 1949 Resistance Monument, the campscape was already half empty when in 1970 the National Monument Camp Westerbork was unveiled, and in 1983, three kilometres away from the silence zone, the Memorial Centre  Camp Westerbork was opened. From then on Jewish survivors held regular commemorations and the annual number of visitors rose constantly, reaching 180,000 in 2019. Since 2000 the Memorial Center has made room for research and presentations on the wider biography of the site, but confronted itself in 2008 with strong protests against its temporary exhibition of the NSB period, after which the museum and the “holy ground” of the campscape have become separated spaces, the latter mainly dedicated to Holocaust commemoration. Yet, within the current context of a growing competition of Holocaust and postcolonial memories, and the refugee issue, the memorialization of the various groups which went through Westerbork and Schattenberg, and their divergent experiences including the role of the perpetrators, remains contested up to today.

Enduring exclusions of the Roma

page_blocks.text: In 1995, the Dutch journalist Aad Wagenaar published the book “Settela”. With a familiar face the cover, that of the girl peeking out intently for something or someone as the carrigage doors close during the transport out of Westerbork (1). Wagenaar attempted to find out who the girl was and in doing so “undo” the anonymization of the victims of the Holocaust. The girl, however anonymous, was not unknown, however.  She was perhaps the most well known still of the so called Westerbork movie, a footage filmed in the camp in 1943 by order of commander Gemmeker and for better than six decades, the girl stood for the Jewish children lost in the brutalities of the Holocaust. But, as in the case of the movie itself, despite the wealthy material offered by this only authentic footage inside a Nazi concentration camps, anonimity and misappropriations seem to have marked the afterlife of this victim. Wagenaar reached a surprising conclusion, after a long search in the Netherlands and abroad, as he did gave the girl back her name: Settela Steinbach. She was a member of the Roma community, not Jewish,  having been deported on the transport of May 19th, 1944. (2)

Enduring exclusions of the Roma

page_blocks.text:
Wagenaar’s quest is interesting out of a number of reasons which have to do with the memory dynamics around the Roma Holocaust, or Porajmos (the “Devouring”). The first is evident in the uncertain number of victims, which today still ranges from 250000 to 1,5 million, a reality which has to do with the lack of censuses before, the destruction of Nazi records but also with the politics of memory regarding this episode. Several authors have pointed to the forgetting of this side of the Holocaust, also determined by the contemporary politics of exclusion that the community still faces. Indeed, there is a peculiar dynamics around the way the Porajmos is remembered. If Settela is known today, not the same can be said about the context which led to her death. This type of historical representation, personalized and obviously an attempt to focus on the victim often leaves a blankspot in the understanding of the why the roots of the Sinti and Roma during the racial persecutions of the Nazi regime .Although the Rromani Holocaust continues to be debated, often denied, more often than not minimized, the existing debates have focused first and foremost on the recognition of the extent of the repression against the Roma and its place in the history of the Holocaust.

From 1899 through the Nazis' ascension in 1933, German legislators introduced law after law to restrict the rights of the Roma by surveilling them, keeping them out of public areas, and limiting the places where they could settle. Laws forbade them from entering many swimming pools or parks and whole sections of the country were off-limits for them. Police even had the right to arrest virtually any Roma they wanted without cause. The prevailing thinking was that any time a Gypsy was behind bars, the country was a safer place.

Unlike other survivors of the Holocaust, the Roma survivors hardly received any recognition or reparations for the suffering they had endured. In fact, even after the Nazis' reign ended in 1945, racism against the Roma endured to the point that some argued they didn't deserve any redress for the genocide.

data.title: Roma caravans

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: Enduring exclusions of the Roma
Enduring exclusions of the Roma

page_blocks.text: The memory politics around the Porajmos weaves in seamlessly with the genesis and endurance of politics of exclusion almost 70 years ago. Indeed, the history in the 1920-1930s of the Sinti and Roma in Europe suggests these politics did not happen suddenly with the NS regime. In Norway, for instance, In Norway, under a "racial purity" programme that began in the 30s and lasted into the 50s, about 500 Gypsy women were sterilised. But all over Europe, after the shock of the First World War and the dissolution of older imperial order, in particular, questions about a “modern” society, with a renewed social condition were ripe, and in that, many of the discussions about a standardization of living conditions, and of social order.

The Roma in the Netherlands are a good example of these dynamics. Towards 1890, the direct target of the policy of restrictions of access in the country were mainly small groups of Hungarian Roma, which for a first time were named “Zigeuners”; this in contrast to the older, local Sinti nomads with papers, who were generally allowed to travel. Otherwise, in the 1920-1930s they were as “foreign” as other categories before them. The Roma were subjected to The reception of the newcomers in the 1930s was determined by the “Alien Act” of 1849, which was primarily meant to bar individuals who were presumably a possible charge and unwanted responsibility for the Dutch state from staying. The borders were accessible and individuals could stay without a work permit, in the sense that they were not illegal even if their permits had expired. In the 19th century, the primary concern was with the poor and working-class, who could become troublesome citizens. The Roma, in fact were caught in a gradually tightening bureacratization of state control. In the Netherlands, the legislation was tightened only after the First World War, when foreign soldiers and no less than 2 million Belgium refugees entered the country of which many were housed, for a first time, in temporary refugee camps. Travelling without passports would become more difficult in Europe after the democratic success of the introduction of universal suffrage in 1918-19. With the German and Russian revolutions, there was fear for communist agitators to stay in the Netherlands. It strengthened the nationalism of governments now having to take care of citizens wanting to protect their national welfare against the “competition” of others. The 1930s economic crisis further strengthened the wish for protectionism against the competition from foreign German-Jewish businessmen for instance.

In the 1920s, what emerged was a concern with an asocial” lifestyle, that escaped these this drive for modernizing and imprinting new values to social cohabitation. From interests in demography, to interests in improving housing conditions, there was, in the modernization of the post First Wolrd War period, evident interest questions of hygiene, modernization and eugenics (the science of the genetic quality of human population) were closely linked and in earnest practices allover Europe. Eastern Europe, evidently more impoverished in the aftermath of the demise of empires, was even more prone to this type of thought. More so, the end of the First World War in Eastern and central Europe did not only bring about a long struggle for the nation state but equally a political bickering about who should be part of this nation-state. The Roma and the Jewish communities were the problematic knots of debate in the Paris Conference establishing the new nation states after the end of the First World War, in 1919. All states objected to the rights of citizenship for these two categories.

This affected the Roma and Sinti community,  particularly as in Eastern Europe,   a situation which was part rather than the cause of their denomination on racial terms of the Nazi regime.  In those debates, a particular notion of isolation, of “asocial” kept re-appearing. Interestingly, it was the same status and term which led to the repression during the war. The ‘asocial” denomination had, in fact, a longer history in defining an exceptional and criminalized status in the interwar period. Indeed, same as many others, the “Dutch” girl fled Germany together with her family to escape their status as were pariahs, criminalized by policies of sterilization under the „Law for the prevention of Hereditarily Diseased Offspring”. In 1935 they were even stripped of their German citizenship.  But the term verged from the social denomination to a political perspective across Europe and was however more widely employed at the time, in a discourse which had to do with the interest in social ordering and principles. Two sites in this project, Westerbork and Falstad, are relevant to understand the usage of the term, as many of the “asocial youth”, some of them early refugees, would finally reach Westerbork. Falstad, in Norway, was an educational facility in the 1930s for “asocial” youth, expected to be reintegrated in society through means which were often considered abusive by witnesses and subjects of interest.
