page_blocks.text: For instance, in Czechia, in 1942, two camps were transformed into camps for Roma, Lety and Hodonin, “for Gypsies or Gypsies of mixed race” or for persons leading a “Gypsy way of life”. With very few exceptions they were registered in fact as “Czech citizens” in Auschwitz. But it was exactly this uncertain status, between the lack of recognition as citizens in the home countries, but a prejudiced adherence to one society or another, even despite their own interests or wishes, that reflected also on the remembrance of the Porajmos.

data.title: Roma caravans

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: Enduring exclusions of the Roma
Enduring exclusions of the Roma

page_blocks.text: Memory followed, in fact, a pattern of exclusion and state repression which has straddled the Second World and is equally visible in European memory culture since then, even during the Cold War. The history tends to be coloured by the perception of the community today, which is still discriminated against allover Europe and also associated with more recent debates. The Roma have been a contemporary debate due to their massive emigration from Eastern Europe after 1989 and their improvised and temporary lifestyle in the regions where they chose to stop. The expulsions from France to countries in the postsocialist space, especially Romania, have held the news in the middle of the years 2000.

The way this memory intersects with the war is complex. In the socialist system, the Roma’s refusal of authority made the community equally singled out. After the war, the socialist project emerged around the “anti-fascist” and anti-war ideas, where the basic social rights - accommodation, work - were the prized promises of the regimes for their citizens, in opposition to the “capitalist” idea, which was also symbolized by the Nazi (defeated) regime in Eastern Europe. The Roma were then a symbolic category, but ambivalent particularly because of their refusal to abide by the promises of the new regime. It is illustrative that the Roma site of Lety was memorialized already ten years after the war. The 1960, the Czechoslovak government fonded a film on the Lety camp, “Don’t forget about that little girl” speaking about the deportations in 1942 and 1943 (5). At about the same time, the Czechoslovak government led a coercive sterilisation programof Romani women. Members of the Roma community were continuously singled out either for their refusal to work or due to xenophobia which continued regardless of ethnicity blind pretences of state socialism.  

The same fears about citizenship have been visible ever since. In 1993,  when Czechoslovalia split into different political entities, there were considerable fears about the citizenship rights of the Roma population. “Migrants”, that is those who had lived in Slovakia rather than the Czech Republic were evidently targeted in this move, among them the Roma.

data.title: Westerbork
data.description: The Westerbork camp in the Netherlands testifies to overlapping histories of politics of exclusion and inclusion. It was established in 1939, after the Dutch borders were closed down for refugees by the government, as a central refugee camp for Jews who fled from Germany and Anschluss Austria. In total, after Hitler’s ascent to power in 1933, almost 32,000 German Jews found refuge in the Netherlands, some 10,000 after the 1938 November or Kristallnacht pogroms. At the beginning of the German occupation in May 1940 it hosted only 750 refugees, but when the Nazis turned the refugee camp into a transit camp in July 1942 the camp was enlarged with new barracks for Dutch Jews. Already since February 1941 Dutch and German Jews were caught by Nazi raids (razzia’s) in the Amsterdam Judenviertel and in other cities, but from July 1942 until the beginning of the railway strike of September 1944 the Polizeiliches Judendurchgangslager Westerbork served that function. In close cooperation with the Amsterdam Jewish Council (Joodse Raad) at about 107,000 (of a total of 145,000 Dutch Jews), and 245 Sinti and Roma, of 97 transports were selected for weekly deportations to concentration and extermination camps in Germany and Eastern Europe, most of them to Auschwitz-Birkenau and Sobibor. The façade of a seemingly peaceful place where people waited in fear on the deadly transports was described in painful details by the Dutch journalist Philip Mechanicus in his camp diary In Depot and in the letters and diaries of Etty Hillesum, and filmed by the German-Jewish photographer Rudolf Breslauer for his 1944 Westerbork film, of which the footage (since 2017 registered as UNESCO Memory of the World) contains the only known real-life moving images of a Nazi train transport. Only 5,000 deportees survived the war. After Poland, the Germans were nowhere more successful in the extermination of Jews than in the Netherlands.  Yet the camp was controlled by only a few German SS officers, with help of some SS trained volunteers from German and Amsterdam police battalions and the Dutch Waffen SS, housed in the nearby SS camp Hooghalen, or Heidelager. The Dutch military police (Marechaussee) continued to guard the camp inside, assisted by a Jewish camp police. The latter, the OD (Ordnungsdienst), distinctive in their green overalls (since 1943) who had to help with the transports, garnered the worst reputation among Dutch Jewish inmates as the ‘Jewish SS’.  Westerbork underwent a new transformation after the liberation, when between 1945 and 1948 it came to serve as an internment camp for members of the Dutch National Socialist Party (NSB), SS volunteers and other people suspected of having collaborated with the Nazis. It also briefly served as a training base for soldiers during the Indonesian War of Independence  (1945-1949) and a camp for Dutch repatriates from the Dutch Indies. From 1951 to 1970 the camp, renamed Schattenberg, became the residence of a large part of former Moluccan soldiers of the Royal Netherlands East Indies Army  (KNIL) with their families, who left the island of Ambon after the Indonesian repression of their independence movement. Two decades after living in the camp, the Moluccans saw their camp demolished after the government approved the project of the Westerbork Synthesis Radio Telescope on the campscape. The Schattenberg community was relocated to surrounding villages. With the exception of the camp commander’s house and the 1949 Resistance Monument, the campscape was already half empty when in 1970 the National Monument Camp Westerbork was unveiled, and in 1983, three kilometres away from the silence zone, the Memorial Centre  Camp Westerbork was opened. From then on Jewish survivors held regular commemorations and the annual number of visitors rose constantly, reaching 180,000 in 2019. Since 2000 the Memorial Center has made room for research and presentations on the wider biography of the site, but confronted itself in 2008 with strong protests against its temporary exhibition of the NSB period, after which the museum and the “holy ground” of the campscape have become separated spaces, the latter mainly dedicated to Holocaust commemoration. Yet, within the current context of a growing competition of Holocaust and postcolonial memories, and the refugee issue, the memorialization of the various groups which went through Westerbork and Schattenberg, and their divergent experiences including the role of the perpetrators, remains contested up to today.

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: The erasure of refugees in Westerbork
The KNIL Veterans and “national” heritage
The postcolonial “blankspot”
Representing perpetrators through heritage
The trace of the political Left
Dynamics of the Jewish memory of resistance around Westerbork
Divided memories and rights in Westerbork
The ambivalent memory of state involvement in Westerbork
Enduring exclusions of the Roma

title: Providing Digital Access to the Commandants House at Westerbork

page_blocks.text: The most obvious remnant of the camp is a dilapidated green and white painted timber house. This building is the former home of the Albert Conrad Gemmeker, the commandant of Westerbork during the transit camp period. In 2015, the house was enclosed within a glass and steel structure in order to protect it from further degradation, facilitate the hosting of educational events and cultural activities, and memorialise one of the last remaining buildings of Kamp Westerbork. In its present form it is inaccessible to the casual visitor.

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: Providing Digital Access to the Commandants House at Westerbork

page_blocks.text: During the Accessing Campscapes project, research at Westerbork centred on the seldom discussed and contentious issue of perpetratorship. Hence, the house was a point of departure for these discussions. Alongside cultural memory and historical research, the team focused on ways to draw upon digital humanities as a means of providing access to sites and narratives connected to this topic.

In conjunction with partners at ScanLAB projects, a survey of the Commandant’s House was undertaken. A highly detailed 3D point cloud was produced using terrestrial laser scanning of the interior and exterior of the building and its immediate environment. The resulting data provides the opportunity to produce interactive, static or fly-through 3D models which can be accessed and researched remotely.

attachments.caption: Commandant’s House 3D Model Report © ScanLAB Projects

data.title: Commandant’s House 3D Model Report © ScanLAB Projects
creator: ScanLAB Projects
data.description: Series of 3D images of the interior and exterior of The Commandant's House

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: Providing Digital Access to the Commandants House at Westerbork

page_blocks.text: The 3D model allows digital access to the space for visitors and allows modern additions (such as the glass enclosure) to be digitally removed. The scans have formed the basis of an innovative interactive VR tool developed by 4D lab and Spinlab at the University of Amsterdam which allows individual users to experience testimony, video materials, information recorded an earlier during archaeological survey of the house by Ivar Schute and other sources within the digital space. Users can experience a biography of the building, and engage with debates around the role and memorialisation of sites connected to perpetratorship.

page_blocks.text: Within the terrain of the former Westerbork transit camp, a survey was first carried out in the vicinity of the camp crematorium. Here, between 1943 and 1945, individuals who died or were killed within the camp were cremated. Demolished in 1951, the presumed location of the crematorium structure was marked by steel posts by the Westerbork memorial. The aim of the Accessing Campscapes research was to confirm the accuracy of these markers and determine whether any buried traces of the building survived at this location.

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: Visualising Campscapes - Heidelager, Westerbork

file.type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, comment: "cmp3.10.3.2Lq3 0x96a09810"

page_blocks.text:
A technique called Ground Penetrating Radar (GPR) was used to survey what remained beneath the ground. This method emits electromagnetic (EM) signals through the earth’s surface in order to record the dimensions and composition of subsurface anomalies. GPS and total station technologies were used to record the positions of above-ground features and the survey grid. 

 

The survey confirmed that at a depth of 0.65m substantial anomalies are present which are most likely associated with the demolished crematoria structures. These were present approximately 10m to the east of the current steel posts, confirming that these are inaccurately placed.

attachments.caption: GPR survey results from Westerbork crematoria, overlain by an outline of the structures taken from the architectural plan (shown in purple). The area marked by the steel posts (shown as a black dashed line) is also depicted on the image. Strong reflections are coloured red in the image. © Centre of Archaeology (Private)

data.title: GPR survey results from Westerbork crematoria, overlain by an outline of the structures taken from the architectural plan (shown in purple). The area marked by the steel posts (shown as a black dashed line) is also depicted on the image. Strong reflections are coloured red in the image. © Centre of Archaeology
creator: Centre of Archaeology

The area marked by the steel posts (shown as a black dashed line) is also depicted on the image. Strong reflections are coloured red in the image

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: Visualising Campscapes - Heidelager, Westerbork

page_blocks.text:
A second survey was carried out at the nearby SS camp Hooghalen (or Heidelager) which was probably built around 1941 as a camp for the unemployed completing agricultural tasks. When Westerbork became a transit camp, it was controlled by a limited number of SS officers who were housed in Heidelager. 

 

Two survey grids were established at Heiderlager and these were positioned (with the aid of a georectified 1944 aerial image) to account for the expected locations of the former barrack buildings in the southern section of the camp.

attachments.caption: Selected Item: Aerial Image of Heidelager from 1944 (left) and a modern aerial image from 2017 (right)

data.title: Aerial Image of Heidelager from 1944 (left) and a modern aerial image from 2017 (right) © I.Schute, Centre of Archaeology
creator: I.Schute
Centre of Archaeology
data.description: Aerial Image of Heidelager from 1944 (left) and a modern aerial image from 2017

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: Visualising Campscapes - Heidelager, Westerbork

page_blocks.text: GPR survey was once again employed to search beneath the ground. This survey proved successful in confirming that buried remains exist across the targeted areas. These remains included features associated with the former barrack buildings, including their foundations, and infrastructure (for example drains and sewers).

attachments.caption: GPR results from Heiderlager grid 1, depth 0.35m (top left), with interpretation (bottom left) and the results overlain onto a 1944 aerial image(right. Grid 2 location is also illustrated (yellow rectangle) as is the existing building on the site (black square). © Centre of Archaeology

data.title: GPR results from Heiderlager grid 1, depth 0.35m (top left), with interpretation (bottom left) and the results overlain onto a 1944 aerial image(right. Grid 2 location is also illustrated (yellow rectangle) as is the existing building on the site (black square). © Centre of Archaeology.
creator: Centre of Archaeology

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: Visualising Campscapes - Heidelager, Westerbork

page_blocks.text: The proven success of GPR as a means of locating and visualising buried remains has been replicated at the sites of Westerbork crematorium and Heidelager. Evidence regarding the survival, construction and location of the buried buildings has been provided and it has been demonstrated that corrections are needed to former historical interpretations.

title: Visualising Stara Gradiška’s Penal Landscape
credits: Reuse of Campscapes; Visualising Campscapes; Competing Victimhoods

page_blocks.text: Stara Gradiška in Croatia is a former prisoner of war camp and penitentiary that was used from 1799 to the early 1990s. Founded on the ruins of the ancient Roman city Servitium, the site was situated in a strategic location during the Ottoman period. A fortress was built in this area in 1715 which became a prison for French POWs in 1799. After the end of WWI and the fall of the Austrian-Hungarian Empire, Stara Gradiška served as a prison for POWs of the newly-formed Kingdom of Yugoslavia.

data.title: A scene from the 3D model of Stara Gradiška © ScanLAB Projects
creator: ScanLAB Projects
data.description: A scene from the 3D model of Stara Gradiška

page_blocks.text: Between 1942 and 1945, under the authority of the Ustaše, the former prison was converted into a concentration camp within the Jasenovac complex. It was known as Camp V Stara Gradiška. The names and details of almost 13,000 people killed in this camp have been confirmed. During World War II the camp and its infamous Tower became a place where violent crimes were committed against women and children. The effect of these crimes on national consciousness in Croatia remains to this day.

page_blocks.text: During the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia era, Stara Gradiska became a notorious political prison. From May 1945 the Communist/Socialist authorities used it as a POW camp for Ustaše, Četniks, Nazis, Fascists, and perceived enemies of the Communist regime. After the Yugoslav-Soviet split in 1948, many supporters of Stalin were interred. Following the “Croatian Spring” uprising in 1971 many Croatian intellectuals, students and citizens were incarcerated there including the Croatian intellectual, poet and later president of the Croatian Liberal Party (HSLS) Vlado Gotovac, and two presidents of the Republic of Croatia - Franjo Tudjman and Stjepan Mesic.

data.author: Ivo Dilber
data.titleOfBookOrArticle:
Memories on the years spent in Yugoslavian communist prison/camp 
Original title in Croatian: Sjećanja na godine provedene u jugoslavenskom komunističkom logoru

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: Visualising Stara Gradiška’s Penal Landscape

file.original_filename: Memory of the priest Ivo Dilber imprisoned in 1945 communist period.pdf

page_blocks.text: The Penitentiary Rehabilitation Centre was disbanded in 1990, but Stara Gradiška became a camp again during The Croatian War of Independence. Between 1991-1993 the Serbian army interred Croats and other non-Serbians. Memory dynamics, architecture and material culture attest to centuries of conflict and persecution at Stara Gradiška, but in Croatian contemporary collective memory, the war of the 1990s is prevalent.

Augustin Franić, KPD Stara Gradiška mučilište i gubilište hrvatskih
političkih osuđenika, 2009, 304 pages (review of the book)

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: intro [DO NOT REMOVE]
Visualising Stara Gradiška’s Penal Landscape

page_blocks.text: Established in 2014, the revisionist far-right NGO “Society for Researching the Triple Jasenovac Camp” (in Croatian: Društvo za istraživanje trostrukog logora Jasenovac) have barely mentioned Stara Gradiška in their theory that the Jasenovac brickworks served as a post-war communist camp.  This demonstrates their aim to distort the sites’ stories by denying Ustaše history and the Holocaust while ignoring research around Stara Gradiška.

data.title: Stjepan Razum interview (revisionism - Jasenovac Ustaše camp diminshed, communist camp put forward)
data.author: Stjepan Razum
data.titleOfBookOrArticle:
U Jasenovcu su partizani svoje zločine podmetali ustašama - to ćemo i dokazati!
(In Jasenovac partisans imposed their crimes to Ustaše - and we will prove it!)

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: Visualising Stara Gradiška’s Penal Landscape

page_blocks.text: The memory space is marked by competing victimhoods as the prison and the camp are linked with the victims of different conflicts throughout its use. Stara Gradiška’s multi-layered and complex evidence of occupation and incarceration is also rapidly disappearing due to neglect and vandalism.  Digital recording and preservation of this site was thus deemed vitally important.

attachments.caption: Photograph of the Stara Gradiška complex taken in  2017 © Centre of Archaeology

data.title: Part of the Stara Gradiška complex in 2017 © Centre of Archaeology
creator: Centre of Archaeology
data.description: Photograph of part of the Stara Gradiška complex taken in 2017

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: Visualising Stara Gradiška’s Penal Landscape

page_blocks.text: As part of the Accessing Campscapes project, detailed recording was undertaken of the former camp hospital, where people were imprisoned, tortured and killed at various points throughout the 20th century. During the Ustaše period, this building was known as “Hotel Gagro” and acts of torture and executions were carried out in its basement. Several internal features and furnishings are preserved within this structure, but it remains inaccessible to the general public because of its position on private land (a builder’s yard) and its dilapidated state.

Ilija Jakovljević, Konclogor na Savi (memoarska proza), 1999

creator: © Centre of Archaeology
data.description: Photograph of one of the rooms within the camp hospital “Hotel Gagro” taken in 2017

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: Visualising Stara Gradiška’s Penal Landscape

page_blocks.text: A landscape model was created of the camp terrain and former hospital building using a combination of techniques. Terrestrial laser scanning of the interior and exterior of the building and its immediate environment was merged with a photogrammetry survey undertaken using a drone. Collectively, these techniques facilitated detailed analysis of the campscape. The uses of this model are wide-ranging in scope.

attachments.caption: A drone survey being carried out at Stara Gradiška © Centre of Archaeology

data.title: A drone survey being carried out at Stara Gradiška © Centre of Archaeology
creator: Centre of Archaeology
data.description: Photograph of a drone survey being carried out at Stara Gradiška

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: Visualising Stara Gradiška’s Penal Landscape

page_blocks.text: Primarily, the former hospital building, which is inaccessible due to its location and current condition, has been analysed and is now available for use by specialists and the wider international community. Floorplans of the building have been created, graffiti (dating to various periods) has been documented, and the building has been digitally preserved, ensuring its availability for future research and providing an important resource for future conservation and protection works.

page_blocks.text: The mapping exercise has provided new material for use in an exhibition at the Jasenovac Memorial Museum, thus raising awareness of the importance of the site, and highlighting the role that it played in the Jasenovac camp complex. The many layers of Stara Gradiška’s history have also been recorded in order to illustrate its temporal and spatial evolution, and the competing memories connected to the campscape.

attachments.caption: Digital exhibition 2019 relating to Stara Gradiska)

data.title: digital exhibition 2019 (in relation to Stara Gradiska)

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: Visualising Stara Gradiška’s Penal Landscape

data.title: Jasenovac
data.description:
The Jasenovac camp in Croatia testifies to the ways in which national authoritarian movements thrived in Europe in the shadow of Nazi Germany and to their enduring influence on contemporary social and political divisions. During the war, Jasenovac was the largest complex of concentration, incarceration, forced labour and death camps scattered in the Independent State of Croatia (Nezavisna Država Hrvatska - NDH), a fascist puppet state. Between 1941 and 1945, the Roman-Catholic Croatian Ustaše with the help of their followers (among them Bosnian Muslims recruited by the Waffen SS) systematically exterminated Jews, Roma, Serbs, Croats and others who opposed Ustaše ideology.  Although contested and subject to continuous politically charged debates, the number of (registered) victims of Jasenovac currently established by the Croat Jasenovac Memorial Site stands at 83,811.
After WWII and the imposition of state socialism in Yugoslavia, the camp came to symbolize the “glorious anti-fascist struggle” captured in Tito’s slogan of “Brotherhood and Unity”, which aimed to aid postwar inter-ethnic consensus. This was reflected in the now-iconic “Stone Flower” monument designed by Bogdan Bogdanovic which was inaugurated, along with a museum, at the location of the former Camp III (Brickworks) in 1968. Although Jasenovac was the most important site of commemoration in Yugoslavia, the nature of the regime did not allow sufficient agency for independent scholarship related to this campscape and the crimes of WWII in general. In the wake of new wars in the 1990s, the number of Jasenovac victims (which had already been overestimated since 1946 in order to justify large wartime reparations from Germany), soon became a key element in the political use of memory. In the 1980s and 1990s, new national tensions in the former Yugoslavia came to be analysed through the prism of past conflicts, creating a new set of propaganda activities and manipulations with regards to the number of victims and visual representations of the Jasenovac tragedy. In 1988, a second permanent exhibition was opened, full of nationalist undertones that fueled ethnic tensions and divisions between Serbs and Croats. This exhibition was demolished during the 1990s dissolution wars. At the same time, the former camp Stara Gradiška (one of Jasenovac’s sub camps) with its torture centre “Hotel Gagro”, was reused as a prison camp in Yugoslavia and as a camp during the 1990s.
After the 1990s wars, the contested legacy of Jasenovac continued to be reflected in the spatial division of the terrain of the former main camp, located on two sides of the River Sava - a national border established in 1991 - which nowadays marks the boundary between Croatia and Republika Srpska, a predominantly Serbian part of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Since the accession of Croatia to the European Union in 2013, this border further separates - politically and symbolically - the 28th EU member state from other countries in the former Yugoslavia. A new permanent exhibition opened in 2006 on the Croatian side at the Jasenovac Memorial Site. On the Republika Srpska side, the Donja Gradina Memorial encapsulates the largest mass killing and mass burial site of the Jasenovac complex, with more than 150 marked and unmarked graves. Established in the 1980s, the site still informs visitors that 700,000 people were murdered in Jasenovac, a figure based on statistics already instrumentalized by Serbian politics in the 1980s and used to wage war against Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. Since the 1990s, right-wing Croatian nationalists and Holocaust deniers have continued to downgrade the number of Jasenovac victims and the nature of the camp. They have also suggested that Jasenovac was a postwar communist camp housing a higher number of prisoners than the Ustaše camp, even though the Brickworks camp was already demolished in 1945. The Jasenovac Memorial Site nowadays promotes the individualization of victims as an alternative to the former politicization of the past and the use of photos showing mass deaths. However, in doing so, it finds itself regularly confronted with revisionist responses to the past.

title: Entertainment at Sites of Mass Violence

page_blocks.text: From an archaeological perspective, these topics are seldom discussed beyond simple observations within field reports despite archaeologists at sites of violence uncovering important evidence connected to entertainment and its various functions within campscapes. An examination of historic documents with a focus on materiality also offers the opportunity for new perspectives on violent epochs.

At Treblinka extermination camp [insert link to camp overview page], archaeological excavations of the camp’s waste pit revealed fragments of champagne, beer and wine bottles, beer bottle tops and shot glasses, indicating that the consumption of alcohol was common in the camp, consistent with witness accounts. Photographs taken by the Deputy Camp Commandant reveal that guards had a zoo built for leisure purposes and undertook sporting activities in the camp.

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: Entertainment at Sites of Mass Violence

page_blocks.text: At the nearby labour camp (Treblinka I) [insert link to camp overview page], fueled by alcohol, the SS and Trawniki guards treated the execution of inmates as entertainment. Guards regularly experimented to determine how many people they could shoot with one bullet (Statement of Maks Lewit, 1944, USHMM RG-22.016). Brutal experiments were carried out with different weapons and women were trampled to death by SS men on their horses (Statement of Barbara Zemkevich, USHMM RG-22.016). Exhumations of remains in mass graves from the camp in the 1940s displayed signs of multiple types of trauma supporting these accounts (Sturdy Colls 2016).

attachments.caption: Cymlich, I. and Strawczynski, O. 2007. Escaping Hell in Treblinka. Jerusalem: Yad Vashem

data.title: Reports and investigative materials compiled by the Military Commissions of the Red (Soviet) Army related to the crimes committed by the Nazis and their collaborators on the occupied territories of the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe during WWI
data.description: The collection consists of the investigative materials, reports and statements compiled by the military commissions of the Red (Soviet) Army established for the investigation of the crimes committed by the Nazis and their collaborators on the occupied territories of the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe during WWII

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: Entertainment at Sites of Mass Violence

page_blocks.text: In Lety, a concentration camp for Roma in the Czech Republic, archaeological excavations have revealed fragments of alcohol bottles including beer, wine and spirits which are likely to be linked to the guards. High levels of alcohol consumption is certainly evident in photographs taken in the camp, in which guards can be seen posing with similar bottles to those recovered during the archaeological investigations.

Wine and beer bottle glass were found by archaeologists in Castuera, a Francoist concentration camp in Spain (insert a link to camp overview). Soft drinks such as soda and sarsaparilla were also recorded. As has been noted in relation to other camps, in Castuera, the use of extreme violence and the execution of inmates inside the camp was used as a form of entertainment. Materiality of this is evident in the area of the latrines, which were deliberately visible to humiliate prisoners (González-Ruibal 2016). As survivors have narrated, guards usually shot inmates during their use for their own enjoyment (link to icon).

data.title: Fragments of bottles documented at Castuera concentration camp

page_blocks.text: Wires were used to immobilize, vex and transport prisoners. The inmates documented that in one of the mass graves located in the town’s municipal cemetery, victims were tied in pairs at their wrists and elbows. Two men were brutally tied by their necks. Inside Mass Grave 1, a bottle of wine was also documented suggesting that perpetrators were drunk during the executions and threw the bottle on the bodies to humiliate the victims after death. As numerous witnesses have narrated, this behavior was widespread among paramilitary groups that operated inside the camp with the consent of Franco’s military personnel (Muñoz-Encinar 2013).

page_blocks.text: In the “Uranium Gulags” in the Czech Republic, facilities that enabled the camp guards to undertake sporting activities were provided. At the beginning of the 1950s, at least two football pitches were built in the restricted Jáchymov area [insert link to camp overview page here], close to the Nikolaj and Mariánská camps. In winter, former political prisoners remember returning from harsh labour in the mines only then to be forced to remove deep snowdrifts so that the camp guards could play soccer.

page_blocks.text: Preserved camp inventories from the Jáchymov camps list equipment for football players. Athletic activities were also supported by camp commanders. Lists of equipment include javelins, discs, throwing balls, stopwatches, high jump poles and boxing gloves. An interesting “eastern” influence is documented by photographs which have been preserved in the archive of former Jáchymov Mines State Enterprise:  Soviet “advisors” who were present in Jáchymov in the late 1940s and 1950s (experts in mining, geology but also NKVD supervisors) introduced a Russian folk game called “gorodki” (similar to bowling and horseshoes).

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: Entertainment at Sites of Mass Violence

page_blocks.text: Material traces demonstrate how the guards entertained themselves in camps. Whilst some activities provided a form of escapism, even coping mechanisms, others reveal how mass violence and killing became entertainment in themselves. These traces reveal that guards still had basic human needs (Mendelson 2013:610) and provokes important questions relating to perpetratorship and human nature. Questions such as “how could these men transition so easily from activities like playing football to mass murder” might be uncomfortable, but they are vital for scholars and the public to comprehend the events of the 20th Century ‘age of extremes’ (Hobsbawn 1995).

title: Unearthing the hidden past in Castuera concentration camp
credits: Human Remains, Materiality, Forensic, Evidence, Silencing memory, Claims of victimhood

page_blocks.text: In January 2011, a mass grave containing the bodies of victims of Castuera concentration camp, established after the Spanish Civil War (1936-1939), was discovered by archaeologists at the town’s municipal cemetery. Shortly afterwards, two further mass graves were exhumed and the bodies of thirty-six men recovered. While two of the graves contained the corpses of camp victims, the third was related to a later period (1943) and contained the remains of three guerrilla men executed during Franco’s dictatorship. The archaeological projects conducted by Laura Muñoz-Encinar in 2011 and Alfredo González-Ruibal in 2012 were funded by the Ministry of the Presidency, in accordance with the law 52/2007 of Historical Memory.

page_blocks.text: This law delegates the responsibility for searching and exhuming the graves of the Spanish Civil War and postwar oppression of Franco’s regime to victims’ associations, which are expected to promote excavation projects and hire scientific teams. In Spain, exhumations have become rich and varied processes in which forensic investigations, taking place outside of juridical frameworks, help people make sense of past crimes. Searches for the disappeared, identification of the corpses and their return to relatives have been essential for the reparation of the victims in Spain. Nonetheless, many activists have widely critiqued the role of the State as a bystander, as it has never assumed responsibility directly.

data.title: Law 52/2007 of Historical Memory
data.description: Law 52/2007, technically known as the “Law of 26th of December through which the rights and measures in favour of those who suffered persecution or violence during the Civil War and dictatorship are recognised”.

In the picture, the Mayor of Castuera (Francisco Martos Ortiz), the president of the “Association for the Memory of Castuera Concentration Camp” (Guillermo León) and two relatives of victims who disappeared in the camp accompany the government delegate. The two family members are Libertad Barrero, daughter of José Gonzalez Barrero, Mayor of the town of Zafra during the Second Republic and Ángel Sayabera Miranda, whose mother Carolina Haba, father José Sayabera Miranda and four other members of his family were executed in Castuera.

data.title: Producing History in Spanish Civil War Exhumations. From the Archive to the Grave
data.description: Producing History in Spanish Civil War Exhumations. From the Archive to the Grave offers an ethnographic insight into contemporary mass grave exhumations in the Spanish south-western region of Extremadura. The book explores how the opening of mass graves resulting from Francoist extrajudicial violence has prompted novel social engagements with the history of the killings in the present, which take place at the crossroads between science, law, politics and family experience.

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: Unearthing the hidden past in Castuera concentration camp

page_blocks.text: Between 2000 and 2011, almost five hundred mass graves were exhumed and the bodies of more than seven thousand victims recovered in Spain. Only a few weeks after the completion of the exhumation of the first mass grave in Castuera, the main Spanish conservative party won the general elections. Immediately afterwards, Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy announced the cut of the budget assigned for the fulfillment of the Historical Memory Law, effectively bringing the exhumations to a halt. Since then and until November 2019, no mass grave has been excavated with governmental support, as contemplated by Law 52/2007.

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: Unearthing the hidden past in Castuera concentration camp

page_blocks.text: The research carried out at Castuera allowed experts to investigate, through the archaeological and forensic analysis of mass graves, the forms of Francoist extrajudicial repression that were deployed at the camp. These irregular acts of repression were carried out as a result of the application of War Declaration Decrees (bandos de guerra) between 1936 and 1948. The processes of elimination of those considered enemies of the new regime after the coup d’état on 17 July 1936, constituted the first stage in the Francoist repressive campaign. Neither the identities of the perpetrators, the accounts of their crimes, nor the locations of the graves have been documented.

data.title: Official document of War Declaration Decrees
data.description: War Declaration Decree issued by the Junta de Defensa in Burgos on 28 July 1936 and published in the Boletín Oficial de la Junta de Defensa Nacional on 30 July 1936.  The decree established the pillars of the Francoist repressive system and implemented the military jurisdiction in the rebel area, after the coup d’état against the legitimate government of the Second Republic (1931-1939) on 17 July 1936. Through this decree civil justice was subordinated to military justice

page_blocks.text: As at other locations of mass violence, the excavation of mass graves revealed the first empirical information about the hundreds of people who disappeared in the Castuera camp. Also, in this case, the exhumation process emerged as an alternative space in which evidence of past crimes is constructed outside a judicial investigation. Through the archaeological excavation of the mass graves, it was possible to establish the location of body disposal pits, the number of victims, their perimortem and postmortem treatment, the causes of death and the mode of disposal of the corpses.

page_blocks.text: In the case of Castuera, the individual identification of the victims was, nevertheless, not possible due to poor preservation of the bones and the lack of sources related to the executions. In two cases, a DNA test was performed. However, no positive results were obtained. The exhumed bodies remain unidentified to this day. Following the Spanish exhumation protocol, human remains were buried individually and identified with a case-study number connected to the scientific reports produced in view of a possible identification in the future. Although the bodies could not be identified, archaeological and forensic data facilitated the reconstruction of facts about the past, which emerged as mechanisms that confront the official history of Francoist war and postwar repression.

Unearthing the hidden past in Castuera concentration camp

page_blocks.text: The recovered remains were inhumed in a memorial erected at the municipal cemetery in Castuera and inaugurated in a commemorative ceremony in 2017. The memorial contains five large slabs listing the names of 250 victims of Franco’s repression. The list includes the names of the victims executed after the occupation of the town and the names of inmates of the concentration camp and the local prison. This amount is far lower than the total number of people who lost their lives in Castuera. The research on Castuera is ongoing. The function of the memorial is to provide a dignified burial space for the corpses of the unknown victims of Castuera, and to carve the names of the missing, in order to create a common space for commemoration, and to symbolically mourn the victims of Franco’s repression in the area. However, there is still no memorial at the Castuera concentration camp.

data.title: Memorial to the victims of Franco’s repression in Castuera
data.description: Memorial built inside the town’s municipal cemetery to inhume the remains recovered from the mass graves. The memorial contains five large slabs listing the names of 250 victims of Franco’s repression. The list includes the names of the victims executed after the occupation of the town and the names of inmates of the concentration camp and the local prison. The function of the memorial is to provide a dignified burial space for the corpses of the unknown victims of Castuera, and to carve the names of the missing, in order to create a common and symbolic space for mourning and commemoration

data.title: Castuera concentration camp
creator: Laura Muñoz-Encinar
data.description: Castuera concentration camp remains invisible in the space where it exists

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: Unearthing the hidden past in Castuera concentration camp

data.title: Castuera
data.description:
The Castuera camp, located in southwest Spain, is one of the nearly two hundred concentration camps that existed during the civil war (1936-1939) and the dictatorship of General Francisco Franco (1939-1975). This camp serves as an example of how the concealed and recent traumatic past in Spain has mobilized the claims of victims’ groups, activists, historical memory associations, political parties and academics for the implementation of an official memory and memorialization politics that recognizes and addresses the experience of victims of Francoist violence.
In March 1939, before the imminent end of the war, the rebel Francoist army used two battalions of republican workers (POW) for the construction of the camp. The camp functioned for one year, between March 1939 and 1940. Its main functions were the classification, reeducation and elimination of those considered the enemies of the new regime after the coup d’état against the legitimate government of the Second Republic (1931-1939) on 17 July 1936. It has been estimated that between 15,000 to 20,000 prisoners went through the camp, which included civilians and militaries from different regions of the country. 
Inside the Camp, detainees were segregated into different barracks. Political personalities shared the space with left-wing trade union leaders, republican council officials, army officers and members of guerrilla groups, among others. Many of them were executed as part of the political cleansing carried out by the new authorities. All traces of them were lost in the concentration camp. The inmates that survived were often (re)integrated into the social fabric of the so-called “New Spain” through forced labor and a process of “re-education.” Thousands of them embarked on a journey, which, in the best-case scenario, took them to other concentration camps, prisons or forced labour camps. These repressive centres utilized a technology of pain to realize their aims of humiliation and punishment. Starvation, illness, epidemics and torture characterized the living conditions in the camps and prisons. 
In January 1940, a small group of inmates escaped from the camp and arrived in France. Far from the fate they expected, they were once again turned into prisoners, detained in a different concentration camp and forced to integrate the Foreign Legion or workers’ battalions. Other half-million Spaniards who fled to France trying to escape from Franco's repression suffered the same fate. Nearly 14,000 Spanish refugees died due to the extreme conditions of the French camps. From here, more than 9,000 prisoners were sent to Nazi concentration camps, and approximately 5,500 died throughout Europe. 
The infrastructure of the camp in Castuera was dismantled at the beginning of April 1940. After it ceased to operate, the camp fell into oblivion, undergoing a similar process to those who endured its violence during the dictatorship. With the “pact of forgetting” and the Amnesty Law of 1977 the silence over the episodes that took place at the site continued throughout part of the current democratic period. In 2004, the screening of the documentary “The nightmare of Castuera” to a primetime television audience marked a turning point in the visibility of the camp. From this moment, the Association for the Memory of Castuera Concentration Camp has led the most important actions connected to the memory and recognition of the camp and the victims of Francoist repression in the area. In 2009, after high pressure from the civil society and academics, the privately own land of the camp received the most important heritage protection classification in Spain as Site of Cultural Interest. Despite its new official categorization, the area continues to be used for extensive stockbreeding today.
Archaeological investigations undertaken at the site between 2010 and 2012 and the exhumations of two mass graves that contained the corpses of prisoners from the camp have revealed important information about the functioning of the site and the repressive processes suffered by prisoners. In January 2019, a new law was approved for the recognition of the victims and the implementation of a specific memory politics in the region of Extremadura. However, despite these new developments, the place remains invisible in the space where it exists, unfathomed in the collective memory of society still today. The camp in Castuera, as it is the case for all of Franco’s concentration camps, still awaits the creation of a documentation centre intended to interpret and disseminate the history and memory of the repression exerted inside and outside its fences.

title: Trials to Dinko Šakić and Živan Kuveždić: evaluating transitional justice
credits: collaboration, communism/socialism, Holocaust, perpetrators, purges, transitional justice, retributions, trials

page_blocks.text: During a hearing in 1999, the former Ustaše commander Dinko Šakić remained utterly calm and assured of his innocence, despite the shootings, hangings and starvations occurring under his “leadership” of the main camp III Brickworks in 1944 in the Jasenovac concentration camp. Šakić was sentenced to 20 years imprisonment, the maximum allotted by Croatian law, at the age of 78, 54 years after the Jasenovac concentration camp had ceased to exist. During the trial, Šakić repeated that he had a clear conscience and felt no remorse whatsoever, despite being confronted with many survivors during the juridical proceedings.

page_blocks.text: Due to the continuing efforts of the Jewish Simon Wiesenthal Centre, Šakić was extradited to the Republic of Croatia in 1998. Until then, he had lived in Argentina with his wife Nada (also a guard in the Jasenovac satellite camp Stara Gradiška, half-sister of the commander of all Ustaše camps, Vjekoslav Max Luburić). After the collapse of NDH, Šakić fled to Argentina with the Ustaše Führer Ante Pavelić. After a period of hiding, Šakić began using his real name and started a textile company, while keeping an active role in Croatian immigrant circles. He was also involved in multiple terrorist acts against Yugoslav embassy officials.

data.title: Dinko Šakić´s biography
data.description: Dinko Šakić, commander of Jasenovac concentration camp in 1944

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: Trials to Dinko Šakić and Živan Kuveždić: evaluating transitional justice

page_blocks.text: After the war, Western European countries quickly realized that the harsh punishment and long exclusion of former collaborators prevented reconciliation, and opted for a policy of forgiveness, amnesty, or forgetting (Geiger and Leček, 2018: 13; Huyse, 2014: 353). The opposite happened in the states that fell under the new Eastern Bloc, where a “socialist revolution” occurred coveted by attempts of dealing with Nazism/Fascism (Gieger and Leček, 2018: 7-26).

page_blocks.text: The vast majority of post-war Yugoslav trials testify to the worst Eastern model of retribution processes, including “wild purges” and harsh post-war people's courts. Even the lowest estimates of those killed in these socialist “cleansing” operations in Yugoslavia after the war exceed the worst calculations in the East, and are incomparable to retribution processes in the West (Geiger and Leček, 2018:18-20). The Croatian/Yugoslav post-war reconstruction process is among the most extreme in Europe, alongside Bulgaria and Hungary, regarding the number of enforced death sentences.

page_blocks.text: All 13 ministers of the Independent State of Croatia who were arrested or extradited to Yugoslav authorities were sentenced to death. In comparison with Hungary and Czechoslovakia, where a certain level of court procedures were maintained, “in Yugoslavia, Bulgaria, Poland, and Soviet Union, post-war justice was a parody of the term” (Deak, 2006: 145; quoted in Geiger and Leček, 2018: 24). About the enormous differences between Western and Eastern Europe, Istvan Deak stated that “in Europe we can almost talk about two wars” (Deak, 2015: 7) and similarly numerous studies have confirmed that we can also talk about “two post-war periods” (Geiger, 2018:421 (book)).

page_blocks.text: Research into the history of war collaboration and the post-war reprisals has shown that the punishment in post-war Europe in general depended on the politics being established rather than on the crime itself (Geiger and Leček, 2018: 9; Voisin, 2014). Questions arose “as to how well newly established courts punished the true culprits, since they were primarily selected from among those directly nominated by and connected to ruling political parties” (Geiger and Leček, 2018: 12; Karsai, 2000: 248).

page_blocks.text: In Yugoslavia, where one authoritarian regime was immediately replaced by another (Gieger and Leček, 2018: 421), an example of “unfair” and “set-up” trials resulting in a fast death sentence was that of Živan Kuveždić. This government official in the Independent State of Croatia was a minister without portfolio (a title assigned against his will after Ante Pavelić decided to re-arrange the government with uncompromised politicians in 1943) and was sentenced even after the establishment of regular courts in Yugoslavia in 1948.

page_blocks.text: Kuveždić was a defender of partisans and Serbs prosecuted in the NDH. Evidence showed Kuveždić had saved many people from the camp. 235 people were witnesses for his defence, many of them antifascists and members of the new government. The Yugoslav secret police UDBA had not accepted any appeals from the defendant. “In many other states Kuveždić would have been acquitted of all charges; in some of them he would have been imprisoned, either for a short time, or the imprisonment would have been diminished by general pardons” (Geiger and Leček,  2018: 46-79 and 422).

data.title: Signed statement of witness Mile Adžić in favour to Živan Kuveždić, signed statement of 235 citizens of Ilača, witnessing in favour to Ž. Kuveždić
data.description: During the trial to minister without portfolio in NDH Živan Kuveždić in 1948 and 1949, parliament representative of Socialist Yugoslavia Mile Adžić, as well as as many as 235 citizens of Kuveždić´s hometown, witnessed in his favour. Mile Adžić witnessed that Kuveždić had saved him from the camp, and 235 citizens of Ilača had sent a written statement stating that Kuveždić had never incited racial hatred against the Serbs, and that he was an opponent of the fascist Hitler regime.

page_blocks.text: In 1949 Yugoslavia, Kuveždić was actually innocent, but was nevertheless sentenced to death by shooting, the permanent loss of all civil rights and complete confiscation of property. He was charged by criminal law for actions against the people and the state. Kuveždić was shot at the Zagreb cemetery Mirogoj on 28th of May 1949, and the location of his grave remains unknown (Geiger and Leček, 2018: 76).

page_blocks.text: In present-day Croatia, “dealing with collaboration has left many dissatisfied, fueling divisions and disagreements that have influenced not only the immediate formation of new regimes, but also collective memories and the politics of memory of our time” (Geiger and Leček, 2018: 24). Comparing Kuvedžić´s and Šakić´s trial, Kuveždić was convicted in early communist period of Socialist Yugoslavia, during the undemocratic and totalitarian regime, while Šakić was convicted in democratic system in the Republic of Croatia. Thus we can state that Kuveždić received the most severe punishment for the incomparable less responsibility than Šakić, who, due to the passage of time and of another legal system, was sentenced to, conditionally speaking, milder punishment . The trials of Šakić and Kuveždić plainly point to the contested politics of memory of collaboration in Yugoslavia and Croatia, and histories of biased judicial mechanisms for wartime collaborators and the post-war retribution processes.

data.title: Jasenovac
data.description:
The Jasenovac camp in Croatia testifies to the ways in which national authoritarian movements thrived in Europe in the shadow of Nazi Germany and to their enduring influence on contemporary social and political divisions. During the war, Jasenovac was the largest complex of concentration, incarceration, forced labour and death camps scattered in the Independent State of Croatia (Nezavisna Država Hrvatska - NDH), a fascist puppet state. Between 1941 and 1945, the Roman-Catholic Croatian Ustaše with the help of their followers (among them Bosnian Muslims recruited by the Waffen SS) systematically exterminated Jews, Roma, Serbs, Croats and others who opposed Ustaše ideology.  Although contested and subject to continuous politically charged debates, the number of (registered) victims of Jasenovac currently established by the Croat Jasenovac Memorial Site stands at 83,811.
After WWII and the imposition of state socialism in Yugoslavia, the camp came to symbolize the “glorious anti-fascist struggle” captured in Tito’s slogan of “Brotherhood and Unity”, which aimed to aid postwar inter-ethnic consensus. This was reflected in the now-iconic “Stone Flower” monument designed by Bogdan Bogdanovic which was inaugurated, along with a museum, at the location of the former Camp III (Brickworks) in 1968. Although Jasenovac was the most important site of commemoration in Yugoslavia, the nature of the regime did not allow sufficient agency for independent scholarship related to this campscape and the crimes of WWII in general. In the wake of new wars in the 1990s, the number of Jasenovac victims (which had already been overestimated since 1946 in order to justify large wartime reparations from Germany), soon became a key element in the political use of memory. In the 1980s and 1990s, new national tensions in the former Yugoslavia came to be analysed through the prism of past conflicts, creating a new set of propaganda activities and manipulations with regards to the number of victims and visual representations of the Jasenovac tragedy. In 1988, a second permanent exhibition was opened, full of nationalist undertones that fueled ethnic tensions and divisions between Serbs and Croats. This exhibition was demolished during the 1990s dissolution wars. At the same time, the former camp Stara Gradiška (one of Jasenovac’s sub camps) with its torture centre “Hotel Gagro”, was reused as a prison camp in Yugoslavia and as a camp during the 1990s.
After the 1990s wars, the contested legacy of Jasenovac continued to be reflected in the spatial division of the terrain of the former main camp, located on two sides of the River Sava - a national border established in 1991 - which nowadays marks the boundary between Croatia and Republika Srpska, a predominantly Serbian part of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Since the accession of Croatia to the European Union in 2013, this border further separates - politically and symbolically - the 28th EU member state from other countries in the former Yugoslavia. A new permanent exhibition opened in 2006 on the Croatian side at the Jasenovac Memorial Site. On the Republika Srpska side, the Donja Gradina Memorial encapsulates the largest mass killing and mass burial site of the Jasenovac complex, with more than 150 marked and unmarked graves. Established in the 1980s, the site still informs visitors that 700,000 people were murdered in Jasenovac, a figure based on statistics already instrumentalized by Serbian politics in the 1980s and used to wage war against Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. Since the 1990s, right-wing Croatian nationalists and Holocaust deniers have continued to downgrade the number of Jasenovac victims and the nature of the camp. They have also suggested that Jasenovac was a postwar communist camp housing a higher number of prisoners than the Ustaše camp, even though the Brickworks camp was already demolished in 1945. The Jasenovac Memorial Site nowadays promotes the individualization of victims as an alternative to the former politicization of the past and the use of photos showing mass deaths. However, in doing so, it finds itself regularly confronted with revisionist responses to the past.

title: Suffering of the Roma in the Independent State of Croatia: Forgotten People on the Sidelines of Croatian History
credits: Roma, Porajmos, genocide, Holocaust, commemoration, suffering

page_blocks.text: On 2nd August 2017 in Croatia, on International Roma Genocide Remembrance Day marked at the Roma cemetery Uštica (Jasenovac satellite camp where Roma population was deported and murdered from May 1942), the Roma representative in the Croatian Parliament, Veljko Kajtazi, announced that “the next step and the request of the Roma community will be to build a museum with a permanent exhibition on Roma suffering within the cemetery premises.” He and the Roma association “Kali Sara” in Autumn 2019 informed the public that the museum construction work will be finished by 2nd August 2020, coinciding with the annual commemoration at Uštica.

page_blocks.text: Along with honoring the Roma who lost their lives in the Independent State of Croatia (Croatian acronym: NDH), Uštica commemoration honors 500,000 Roma, representing at least a quarter of their total population at that time, murdered in Nazi-occupied Europe. Croatian Parliament supported the establishment of “the International Remembrance Day of Roma Victims of the Pharraimos (Holocaust)” in December 2014, the year before European Parliament also declared it.  In March 2017 Croatian Parliament officially changed the name of commemoration into “International Roma Genocide Remembrance Day”, or “Samudaripen”, indicating the need to find appropriate ways, and  terminology, to commemorate Roma victims.

page_blocks.text: As part of their migration to Southeastern Europe, the Roma population settled in Croatian territories in the second half of the 14th century. Their coexistence with the domicile population was often marked by repressive and assimilationist state and local policies, based on centuries of prejudices and stereotypes about Roma as asocial, criminals or spies. This state policy against Roma was known as antigypsyism.

data.title: Roma in Jasenovac concentration camp
data.description: The photo of Roma in Jasenovac concentration camp, unkown date, archival signature: 745 JSV 88-05 FR

file.original_filename: Roma in Jasenovac concentration camp 745 JSV 88-05 FR.jpg

page_blocks.text: Antigypsyism was especially present in Croatia during WWII. In April 1941 the pro-fascist Ustaše established the Independent State of Croatia (NDH) with support of fascist Italy and Nazi Germany.  Shortly after the NDH was founded, racial laws that included Roma were implemented which influenced their immediate loss of civil rights and instigated their further systematic (genocidal) persecution. In the summer of 1941, the first cases of Ustaše mass crimes against the Roma were recorded. Most of the Roma were collateral victims of the Ustaše policy trying to suppress the rebellion of Serbian population against their regime.

data.title: Danijel Vojak, “The persecution and suffering of Roma in the Independent State of Croatia, 1941 – 1945”, in: 35. Schlaininger Gespräche: Roma und Sinti von 1938 bis zur Gegenwart, ed. Rudolph Kropf, Gert Poltster. Eisenstadt: Landesmuseum Burgenland 2016., pp. 171-182.
data.author: Danijel Vojak
data.titleOfBookOrArticle: “The persecution and suffering of Roma in the Independent State of Croatia, 1941 – 1945”, in: 35. Schlaininger Gespräche: Roma und Sinti von 1938 bis zur Gegenwart

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: Suffering of the Roma in the Independent State of Croatia: Forgotten People on the Sidelines of Croatian History

page_blocks.text: In July 1941, the Ustaše authorities decided to take the next step in resolving the so-called "Gypsy issue", conducting a census of Roma population. Next was the systematic persecution of the Roma based on the special decree of the NDH Ministry of Internal Affairs enacted on 19 May 1942, upon which most of the Roma from the NDH were deported to Jasenovac camp, especially to the villages Uštica and Donja Gradina, where they were tortured and killed. The Ustaše anti-gypsy policy resulted in almost complete demographic extermination of the Roma population with only 405 declaring as Roma in the first postwar census of  1948.

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: Suffering of the Roma in the Independent State of Croatia: Forgotten People on the Sidelines of Croatian History

page_blocks.text: Very few Roma in Croatia survived the war and of those, even fewer were willing to testify about their experiences. Milan Radosavljevic, a 33-year-old farmer from the village of Novi Jankovci in Srijem, did participate in the prosecutions of those responsible for the genocide in the NDH. He  testified in March 1953 in a criminal case against the Ustaše commander Andrija Artuković, describing how Ustaše forced Roma to dig graves, and how he witnessed numerous killings when Ustaše authorities deported him to Jasenovac concentration camp in May 1942. Radosavljevic witnessed that a lot of his family members (including children) were killed in Jasenovac, and described how he managed to escape and joined partisans at the mountain Psunj, where he stayed until the liberation in 1945.

data.title: Danijel Vojak, “Roma Holocaust in Croatia: from marginalization to formal recognition and commemoration”, in: Beyond the Roma Holocaust: From Resistance to Mobilisation, ed. Thomas M. Buchsbaum, Sławomir Kapralski. Krakow: Österreichische Botschaft Warschau; Taiwpn Universitas, 2017, pp. 131-149.

page_blocks.text: The process of forgetting Roma victims began immediately after WWII ended. The fact that considerable numbers  of the pre-war Roma population lost their lives during the NDH terror wiped out the political or intellectual potential for a  sustainable culture of remembering. New socialist authorities in Croatia and Yugoslavia linked the discourse of cultural memory with the ideological pattern of “Brotherhood and Unity”. Therefore, new socialist political elites, propagating political and national unity, aimed to integrate already formed ethnicities and nationalities under the united principle of Brotherhood and Unity rather than acknowledge distinct groups.

data.title: Danijel Vojak, Filip Tomić, Neven Kovačev, “Remembering the 'Victims of Fascist Terror'” in the Socialist Republic of Croatia, 1970–1990“, History and Memory, 31 (2019.), Nr. 1, pp. 118 -150.
data.author: Danijel Vojak, Filip Tomić, Neven Kovačev
data.titleOfBookOrArticle: Remembering the 'Victims of Fascist Terror'” in the Socialist Republic of Croatia, 1970–1990. History and Memory, 31 (2019), 1

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: Suffering of the Roma in the Independent State of Croatia: Forgotten People on the Sidelines of Croatian History

page_blocks.text: The main focus was given to antifascist attempts (reflected through commemorations) to blur the national differences between victims. They used the collective term “victims of fascist terror (and/or) the occupiers”, hence all ethnic names of Roma victims were anonymised amongst the masses of other victims. Consequently, the question of genocidal suffering of the Roma during the war was entirely erased from the social, political and cultural spheres of Yugoslav and Croatian society. Throughout the period of socialist Yugoslavia, Roma suffering was reduced to an incidental footnote in marginal historiographical papers, or limited to a few sentences from the testimonies of the Roma survivors.

data.title: Danijel Vojak, „Komemoracija romskih žrtava Drugog svjetskog rata u socijalističkoj Hrvatskoj, 1945. – 1991.“ Zgodovinski časopis 72 (2018), Nr. 3-4, pp. 440 – 461.

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: Suffering of the Roma in the Independent State of Croatia: Forgotten People on the Sidelines of Croatian History

page_blocks.text: Paralell to the forgetting of Roma victims, the Yugoslav political elite had been highlighting WWII as the beginning of Roma “emancipation” potentially leading to their equality in socialist Yugoslavia. This wasn´t achieved, primarily because Roma were not recognized as a national minority, but only as an ethnic group. Although the former Ustaše concentration camp Jasenovac was converted into a memorial complex in the late 1960s, Roma suffering was marginalized in the permanent exhibition. The only example of a memorial plaque honoring Roma victims was erected in the village Uštica, which today forms part of Jasenovac Memorial Site. This was erected by Partisan Veterans Federation (SUBNOR) in 1971 when 21 mass graves of Roma were marked. One of the first recorded Roma commemoration in Socialist Republic of Croatia took place in July 1982, when the memorial was visited by 200 members of the cultural-educational association “Rom” from Zagreb.

page_blocks.text: Similar marginalized stances towards the WWII Roma genocide continued with a new democratic government of the Republic of Croatia in the 1990s. Just after the legal recognition of the status of Roma as a national minority in 2002, Roma position was strengthened, including obtaining representatives in the Croatian Parliament which allowed them to successfully impose a need to commemorate Roma victims; with International Remembrance Day of Roma Holocaust Victims marked in Croatia for the first time on 2nd of August 2012 at the Roma cemetery in Uštica. The commemoration was organized by Roma Parliament representative Veljko Kajtazi, Roma parliament and Roma NGOs.

page_blocks.text:
Because of the visible disunity among Romani organizers, first commemorations were contentious and consequently negatively received by the wider public. This was especially evident during the second commemoration in Uštica in August 2013, when a group of Romani organizations commemorated the International Remembrance Day on the 1st rather than  . Nevertheless, along many memory disputes, the construction of the museum dedicated to Roma victims in Jasenovac and NDH has already begun.

 

After consultations with author of this storyline, I was suggested to get rid off the last sentence, as it doesn´t reflect what is happening. After thinking how to finish, the author decided it is better not to touch the complex issue of building the new museum center, which is accentuated at the beginning.

data.title: Jasenovac
data.description:
The Jasenovac camp in Croatia testifies to the ways in which national authoritarian movements thrived in Europe in the shadow of Nazi Germany and to their enduring influence on contemporary social and political divisions. During the war, Jasenovac was the largest complex of concentration, incarceration, forced labour and death camps scattered in the Independent State of Croatia (Nezavisna Država Hrvatska - NDH), a fascist puppet state. Between 1941 and 1945, the Roman-Catholic Croatian Ustaše with the help of their followers (among them Bosnian Muslims recruited by the Waffen SS) systematically exterminated Jews, Roma, Serbs, Croats and others who opposed Ustaše ideology.  Although contested and subject to continuous politically charged debates, the number of (registered) victims of Jasenovac currently established by the Croat Jasenovac Memorial Site stands at 83,811.
After WWII and the imposition of state socialism in Yugoslavia, the camp came to symbolize the “glorious anti-fascist struggle” captured in Tito’s slogan of “Brotherhood and Unity”, which aimed to aid postwar inter-ethnic consensus. This was reflected in the now-iconic “Stone Flower” monument designed by Bogdan Bogdanovic which was inaugurated, along with a museum, at the location of the former Camp III (Brickworks) in 1968. Although Jasenovac was the most important site of commemoration in Yugoslavia, the nature of the regime did not allow sufficient agency for independent scholarship related to this campscape and the crimes of WWII in general. In the wake of new wars in the 1990s, the number of Jasenovac victims (which had already been overestimated since 1946 in order to justify large wartime reparations from Germany), soon became a key element in the political use of memory. In the 1980s and 1990s, new national tensions in the former Yugoslavia came to be analysed through the prism of past conflicts, creating a new set of propaganda activities and manipulations with regards to the number of victims and visual representations of the Jasenovac tragedy. In 1988, a second permanent exhibition was opened, full of nationalist undertones that fueled ethnic tensions and divisions between Serbs and Croats. This exhibition was demolished during the 1990s dissolution wars. At the same time, the former camp Stara Gradiška (one of Jasenovac’s sub camps) with its torture centre “Hotel Gagro”, was reused as a prison camp in Yugoslavia and as a camp during the 1990s.
After the 1990s wars, the contested legacy of Jasenovac continued to be reflected in the spatial division of the terrain of the former main camp, located on two sides of the River Sava - a national border established in 1991 - which nowadays marks the boundary between Croatia and Republika Srpska, a predominantly Serbian part of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Since the accession of Croatia to the European Union in 2013, this border further separates - politically and symbolically - the 28th EU member state from other countries in the former Yugoslavia. A new permanent exhibition opened in 2006 on the Croatian side at the Jasenovac Memorial Site. On the Republika Srpska side, the Donja Gradina Memorial encapsulates the largest mass killing and mass burial site of the Jasenovac complex, with more than 150 marked and unmarked graves. Established in the 1980s, the site still informs visitors that 700,000 people were murdered in Jasenovac, a figure based on statistics already instrumentalized by Serbian politics in the 1980s and used to wage war against Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. Since the 1990s, right-wing Croatian nationalists and Holocaust deniers have continued to downgrade the number of Jasenovac victims and the nature of the camp. They have also suggested that Jasenovac was a postwar communist camp housing a higher number of prisoners than the Ustaše camp, even though the Brickworks camp was already demolished in 1945. The Jasenovac Memorial Site nowadays promotes the individualization of victims as an alternative to the former politicization of the past and the use of photos showing mass deaths. However, in doing so, it finds itself regularly confronted with revisionist responses to the past.

page_blocks.text: On 22nd of March 2019, new theatre play “Eichmann in Jerusalem” was premiered in Zagreb. The play has brought to theatrical life the most horrifying chapters, ranging from sending inmates to gas chambers to obnoxious behaviours of passive bystanders across Europe At the end of the play, the horrors and atrocities of Jasenovac concentration camp were put in context of the total destruction of European Jewry. The tickets were soon sold out, and the play continued to gather lots of visitors from Zagreb and Croatia in the following months.

data.title: theater play Eichmann in Jerusalem

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: The war on numbers: the presence of Jasenovac in Serbian and Croatian politics of memory

page_blocks.text: The “Eichmann in Jerusalem” play, although eagerly received in Zagreb, represents a rare example in prevailing science and arts of historical distortion of WWII, namely Holocaust denial, spreading through Zagreb and Croatia. Starting in 2013, immediately after Croatia joined the EU, and especially  from 2014, the massive revisionist attempts to downplay the crimes committed by the pro-Nazi Ustaše-regime remain even more present in the era of mass media, and stay largely concentrated on diminishing the numbers of Jasenovac camp victims.

data.title: Igor Vukic newspaper article claiming that prisoners weren´t brought to camp to be killed
data.description: Igor Vukic, the president of the far right NGO "Society for Researching Treefold Jasenovac Camp" in Croatia, published an article in Croatian newspapers Glas Koncila (15 December 2013) stating that nobody was brought to Jasenovac on racial basis, because being a Jew or a Serb. Vukić states that almost all prisoners have been brought on ideological basis, because being supporters of partisan-communist movement.

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: The war on numbers: the presence of Jasenovac in Serbian and Croatian politics of memory

page_blocks.text: The highly controversial far-right Croat revisionist NGO “The Society for Research of the Threefold Jasenovac Camp”, established in 2014, consists of those who aren´t professional historians, and worryingly some academics and politicians. It aims to whitewash Ustaše history and “to rehabilitate the regime in its entirety”. Differing from revisionism of Tudjman era, some members of the Society claim that the number of victims of Jasenovac “ranges from 1,000 to 2,000, possibly 3,000 but by no chance more than 5,000” (Ivezic, 2003: 206), figures even more conservative than  revisionist claims supported by Franjo Tudjman’s politics in the 1990s.

data.title: Mladen Ivezic, Jasenovac Numbers
data.description: Among many revisionist literature in the field, Mladen Ivezić´s book Jasenovac Numbers, states that the number of victims of Jasenovac “ranges from 1,000 to 2,000, possibly 3,000 but by no chance more than 5,000” (Ivezic, 2003: 206).

page_blocks.text: In the late 1980s and early 1990s, Tudjman “presented the NDH as one stage in the fulfilment of a long desired dream of national independence”. He did so to assure national and state identity after the fall of Communist/Socialist Yugoslavia. “However, there was no official rehabilitation of that regime, whether in politics or in education” (Odak and Bencic, 2016: 811). Tudjman was a partisan and historian, among the first in SFR Yugoslavia possessing state-forbidden lists of Jasenovac victims showing much lower numbers of victims stated by the Yugoslav government. In his irrational desire to achieve “national reconciliation” between Partisans and Ustaše, during the 1980s and 1990s Tudjman balanced atrocities committed at Jasenovac and Bleiburg estimating both death tolls to 30,000-40,000 victims.

data.title: Odak, Stipe and Bencic “Jasenovac a Past that Does not Pass: The Presence of Jasenovac in Croatian and Serbian Collective Memory of Conflict”, in: East European Politics and Societies and Culture 30(2016) 4: 806-829.

page_blocks.text: When it finally became possible to debate the numbers of victims in SFR Yugoslavia in the 1980s, Tudjman´s approximations of the number of Jasenovac camp victims were closer to two independently conducted research papers by Serbian Bogoljub Kočović (Kočović, 1985) and Croat Vladimir Žerjavić (Žerjavić, 1989). Yet Tudjman is still criticized for historical revisionism to this day, even though he was imprisoned and sentenced for three years in 1981 because he criticized and publicly challenged what was considered to be the “Yugoslav truth”: the sacrosanct number of 700,000 Jasenovac camp victims.

linkedPages.exhibitTitle: The war on numbers: the presence of Jasenovac in Serbian and Croatian politics of memory

page_blocks.text: The origin of current nationally and politically driven war on numbers of Jasenovac camp victims, which remains  the most manipulated and contested in Croatian and Serbian historiography, can be traced to 1946. Yugoslav State Commission for Investigation of the Crimes of the Occupiers and Their Collaborators submitted the following report to the International Military Tribunal in Nürnberg: “a minimum of 600,000 persons, mostly Serbs, followed by Jews, Roma and Croats, were killed in the Jasenovac camp by the end of 1943” (Geiger, 2013: 153). Although the Report was first published in Belgrade in 1947, previous reports submitted in 1946 intentionally overestimated numbers of human losses (1,706,000 overall in Yugoslavia, of which 700,000 Jasenovac victims), primarily to get larger wartime reparations. Both reports, composed without documents but from a few testimonies, became central sources for all later exaggerations and manipulations of the number of Jasenovac victims.

page_blocks.text: The number of 700,000 Jasenovac victims was repeated in encyclopedias and historical textbooks for almost half a century in SFR Yugoslavia, staying deeply embedded in collective memory of all Yugoslav people. In SFR Yugoslavia three official censuses of WWII human losses were conducted in 1944-1947, 1951 and 1964, with  the latter indicating  smaller numbers of victims than the Yugoslav government officially claimed prompting the 1964 census to be immediately forbidden and put under embargo to hide the figures of 597,323 total victims of which 59,461 in Jasenovac camp. The embargo allowed extreme numerical exaggerations to continue, especially of Serbian victims of Jasenovac camp.

page_blocks.text: This exaggeration of numbers escalated during the 1980s and 1990s in an extreme political use of memory in Serbia. In wake of the new war in the 1990s, and especially after the release of the notorious Memorandum of the Serbian Academy of Arts and Science in 1986, in Serbian academic circles, press, and particularly among politicians gathered around Slobodan Milosevic, the numbers of specifically Serbian Jasenovac victims were inflated to more than a million.

Serbian history textbooks which are currently in use operate with the estimate of 600,000-700,000 Jasenovac victims, the number put forward by the Yugoslav State Commission in 1946. On a political level, Serbia, and especially Republika Srpska (BiH), still vocally advocate the number of 700,000 and more Jasenovac victims in domestic and foreign politics.
